## T.C.
 
 <i>abbr.</i> (Teachers) Training College

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> The most widely known game with insects is a game named variously by T.C. students as Butcher Boys (Gisborne, New Plymouth, Kaponga, [405] Te Pohu, Newall, Sth. Wellington), Butcher Bats (Ohau, Takaka), Penny Doctor Beetles (Tauranga, Pipiriki, Rotorua), or Fishing (Morunui). It is a game in which straws which have been suitably moistened with spittle are placed in an insects [sic] hole and are flicked out when the insect bites the end of the straw. Most of the reports of this practice come from the North Island, though it was known in the South as early as 1900 (Waikouaiti). <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,1/404</i>)

 <i>n.</i> the Totalisator Agency Board set up in 1952; any one of its local betting agencies [ORIGIN: acronym, also attrib. below]

"The New Zealand TAB was the first of its type in the world and I have to say it was pretty successful." <i>(Apr 2, 2001,Evening Post,13</i>)

>  It's a day off - with the only difference that Anzac Day is not yet Mondayised - it's off to the football or into the TAB or into the garden. <i>(Apr 25, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),8</i>)

## table
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The constant outflow of crushed quartz and water from the stamp boxes is received on a table, having on it grooves or ripples, containing quicksilver and a large extent of amalgamated copper plates smoothly nailed on. This may be called the silver table; ... The flow then passes over blanket tables, which arrest mechanically all the heavier particles. <i>Ibid.</i> 179 The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings. <i>(1876,TrNZI,8/177</i>) [NOTES: (Goodall Thames Gold-fields)]

>  The battery has three stampers in each box, double cams, quickslver placed in battery boxes, grating perpendicular, with round holes. The copper-plate tables are about 12ft. long by 5ft. wide, and raised about 14in. above the blanket boards; ... [The blankets] appear to be ordinary grey blankets of a very inferior description. <i>(1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,93</i>)

>  <b>MOFFATT</b> Yet still they dig and delve, be the weather foul or fair, / And talk of plush and tables, and a thousand pounds a share. <i>(1896,Adventures by Sea and Land,70,1970 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [a1882] 1896 Moffatt Adventures (1979) 70 [Walter D. Moffatt, d. 3.1.1882: poem]]

>  <b>HEINZ</b> Under the chute board, which carries the water and sand to the head of the table, is the long inclined board called the `table', and on this plush is fitted for its entire length. <i>(1952,Prospecting for Gold,35</i>)

## taboo
 
 <i>v.</i>



 
 <i>adj.</i> [also tabu]

>  The hand which has passed that [of] Rauparaha is tabu to every English gentleman or lady. <i>(Jan 11, 1845,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,1</i>)

>  The Government was patriarchal, and was divided into three classes, all of which were frequently represented by one person, viz.: The prophet, the charmer, and the hereditary head of the tribe, who was "taboo" or sacred; in fact, the institution of the "taboo" was interwoven with all their institutions, and the penalty for breaking it was death. <i>(Feb 1, 1862,Otago Daily Times,2</i>)

>  He who swam in the sacred waters became "taboo". <i>(Dec 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  That near Otaki a chief, who was drowned, had been washed ashore, and in consequence the natives had tabooed, or made sacred, the ground, which precluded persons from proceeding to Wanganui by land. <i>(Jun 12, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2</i>)

>  They also taboo the nearest relatives' hands, that is to say, make them sacred, so that they cannot eat or touch anything with them for a certain perod [sic]. <i>(Sep 5, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3</i>)

>  He was for some time.. tabooed by all on board. <i>(Feb 19, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,20</i>)

>  The process of "tabooing" the lands had caused the natives to meet and talk together. <i>(Aug 16, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,14</i>)

>  Certain warehousemen who were wont to develop the muscles of their legs by climbing Grey-street on their way home, after a hard day's toil, have tabooed the street, and now proceed by round-about roads on their homeward journey. <i>(May 23, 1891,Observer (Auckland),12</i>)

>  The forest in order to preserve it from the fate of similar of its predecessors, has been "tabu'd." <i>(Jan 5, 1878,Grey River Argus,4</i>)

>  Not content with preventing the use of free passes and privilege tickets by through express trains from 16th December to 3rd January, the department has also tabooed all through passenger, mail, or express trains from 23rd December to 3rd January. <i>(Dec 23, 1910,Evening Post,8</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [cf tapu] (See [tapu](../T#tapu))

>  The heathen taboo, as firmly binds the missionary native as it does the unconverted. <i>(Sep 28, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  In the meantime either a system of taboo must be invented, or the party in possession of the claim will most likely have worked out the ground, and departed for fields and pastures new. <i>(Mar 30, 1864,Otago Daily Times,5</i>)

## tai timu
 
 <i>n.</i> with TAI PARI perhaps indicative of the change in time and place of Pakeha vernacular knowledge of Maori Williams 361 <i>Tai (i) ... Sea.: timu `ebb(ing)'</i> (he tai timu<i> `low water'); pari</i> `flowing (of the tide)'. Both were intelligible to many English speakers up to at least the 1930s, and possibly the 1950s in the North Island, as witness the following joke first heard by me as a child in Havelock (South Island) possibly from an original King Country version; and first mentioned as early as 1845 by Walter Brodie in <i>The State of New Zealand </i>where it is attributed to Mr [?initial] Williams. Tim and Paddy were walking along the beach when they came across two Maoris arguing, as it semed to them, ferociously. One was crying out `Tie Tim!' and the other, `Tie Paddy!'. Paddy took to his heels shouting: `You can bloody well tie Tim if you like, but I'm damned if you'll tie Paddy!' Enjoyment of the joke depends not only on knowing the meaning of the Maori forms, but also on a non-Maori perception of Maori /r/ as [d], and failure to hear a devocalised /u/ final. In 1986 it is usually necessary to `prepare' the joke with tedious explanation.

>  <b>POLACK</b> The timber-dealer in conducting his raft down the river at flood tide (<i>tai parre</i>[e-acute],) drops an anchor, (a heavy piece of wood or bag of stones) at the end of the flood (<i>tai pakoa</i>[a1-acute]) in deep water, that he may be enabled to pursue his route at the finish of the ebb (<i>tai timu</i>.) <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/170</i>)

## tailing
 
 <i>n.</i> the docking of a lamb's tail

>  <b>WOODHOUSE</b> We completed the tailing of the hill lambs about midday. <i>(1982,Blue Cliffs,190</i>)

>  Lambing.- The tailing did not reveal many exceptional percentages. <i>(Dec 18, 1918,Otago Witness,27</i>)

>  <b>WELD</b> About a week after the lambing is finished, the operations of castration, tailing, and ear-marking are performed. <i>(1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,10</i>)

>  <b>PERRY</b> The operation of tailing is generally performed with a knife, and care must be taken to have as uniform a dock as possible. <i>(1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,80</i>)

>  <b>AYSON</b> ... as there were wild dogs about I had to follow the lambs about all day, bringing them home at night to camp them near the homestead and sometimes in the yards. That is what they call in Australia `tailing', as the dingoes were very bad in the early days. <i>(1937,Pioneering in Otago,40</i>)

>  <b>BURDON</b> Quite apart from the long, expensive business of dipping scab-infected sheep, the lack of wire fences entailed constant vigilance in tailing and boundary keeping. <i>(1938,High Country,85</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> One year during the eighties we tailed 28,000 lambs from 32,000 ewes. The tailing of so many lambs was a long business, and sometimes it lasted for three or four weeks. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,114,1954 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [cf. tail v.1]

>  <b>ELWELL</b> This watching of sheep and keeping them together was called `tailing'. <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,47</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) 1. the removing of lambs' tails with knife, searing iron or runner ring. [Used loosely to include ear-marking and castration of male lambs at the same time and used mainly in the South Island.] 2. the quiet following of stock as they graze while being driven. [docking two senses in one entry here] (See [docking](../D#docking))

>  WANTED, at Elephant Hill Station, SHEPHERDS, with good dogs , for Mustering and Tailing. <i>(Nov 15, 1872,North Otago Times,5</i>)

>  TAILING LAMBS. <i>(Dec 21, 1904,Otago Witness,33</i>)

>  <b>WELD</b> About a week after the lambing is finished, the operations of castration, tailing and ear-marking are performed. <i>(1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,10</i>)

>  <b>PERRY</b> The operation of tailing is generally performed with a knife ... <i>(1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,80</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> The tailing of so many lambs was a long business, and sometimes it lasted for three or four weeks. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,114</i>)

>  <b>DREAVER</b> For several years I went back to the Wisp to work on a casual basis, mustering and tailing. <i>(1994,Catlins River Wisp Run,57</i>)

>  <b>BARDSLEY</b> tailing: (South Is) docking, castration and earmarking, known as 'marking' in some South Island areas. 2. <i>(2000,Land Girls, The,171</i>)

>  <b>MCGREGOR</b> One of the early tasks which was assigned was 'tailing', not cutting the lambs' tails as the word implies today but driving the flock from one place to another and watching the sheep and keeping them together in wide-open spaces where there were no fences. <i>(1980,Dog's Life, A,3</i>)



## tailing count
 
 <i>n.</i> numbers estimated from animals "tailed"

>  [He] said preliminary figures from Meat and Wool Innovation's annual tailing count suggested a drop in lamb numbers by 1.5 million head this season to 31.6 million. <i>(Nov 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C6</i>)



## tailing ground
 
 <i>n.</i> [cf tail v1, tail shepherding]

>  <b>ELWELL</b> He had caught sight of a native hanging about the `tailing ground'. <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,67</i>)



## tailing muster
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a gathering of ewes and lambs for castration, ear-marking, and the docking of lambs' tails.

>  The effect upon the lambing in the higher districts will no doubt be very serious, and the 'cutting and tailing' muster far short of what, in a more favourable season, might be expected. <i>(Nov 4, 1882,Otago Witness,14</i>)

>  <b>COOP</b> Apart from the tailing muster, which is done on the sheep blocks, ewes and lambs are not handled or brought into the yards ... <i>(1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,27</i>)

>  <b>DOMINY</b> During a tailing muster, in 1990, the runholder noted that the hired man was a 'natural musterer' ... <i>(2001,Calling the Station Home,174</i>)

>  <b>DOMINY</b> The Glenaan tailing muster in 1990 when we brought in the ewes and their lambs from the steep sunny north-facing 'lambing blocks' to the yards ... <i>(2001,Calling the Station Home,195</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> No time is wasted in a tailing muster. If a ewe with a young lamb drags behind, leave her; she'll come in at shearing, and the little lamb is better out of the crush of the yard. <i>(1951,High Country,24</i>)



## tailing out
 
 <i>n.</i> [includes verb & attrib]

>  WANTED two BENCHMEN, two Men for TAILING-OUT; also BUSHMEN and some other Men, for Messrs MALCOLM, RUSSELL & CO.'S, MAKINO STEAM SAW & PLANING MILLS, FEILDING. <i>(Nov 13, 1878,Manawatu Times,3</i>)

>  WANTED, a young MAN accustomed to tailing-out at sawmill. <i>(Aug 7, 1888,Grey River Argus,1</i>)

>  WANTED, two Sawyers (circular and breaking-down); 1 Tailing-out Man; 6 Bushmen (first-class men); Engine-driver, for mill; Man Cook, for mill; General Servant, for East Coast; Canvasser for town; General Servant, country, 15s; Lady to travel, salary and commission. <i>(Oct 24, 1896,Evening Post,1</i>)

>  WANTED - For Motu Sawmill, Competent Man, for Tailing-out; also Man for Breaking-down Bench. <i>(Feb 24, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,1</i>)

>  WANTED, SMART BOY For Tailing-out Machine; also 2 EXPERIENCED TIMBER STACKERS. <i>(Jun 2, 1920,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  WANTED, Smart Boy for Tailing-out, city sawmill, good wages. <i>(Jan 7, 1930,Evening Post,1</i>)

>  MEN AND YOUTHS REQUIRED for tailing-out and yard work, good conditions, weather protection. <i>(Aug 22, 1945,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  WANTED - A bullock-driver; tailing-out man; several farm hands and milkers; married couples. <i>(Sep 26, 1904,Bush Advocate,3</i>)

>  It was then cut into fire sized blocks, pulled away from the saw and thrown in the big heap. This was called `tailing out'. <i>(1987,Province: New Nelson Writing,60</i>)

>  <b>JACKSON</b> [He] shouted greetings to men in black singlets ..., tailing out. He was answered by the ... drone of the breaking-down saw as it bit into a pine log. <i>(1988,Rainshadow,90</i>)



## tailing paddock
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a fenced area in which lambs are tailed/docked, earmarked and where male lambs are emasculated.

>  <b>STEVENS</b> If there are many ewes with twin lambs the dog and the shepherd can spend a profitable half-hour while the yards are being transported and erected in the next tailing paddock. <i>(1958,Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,59</i>)



## tailing pen
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a temporary paddock yard made with scrim or netting for the tailing, marking or docking of lambs.

>  At the narrow end the tailing pen is made. <i>(1919,Livestock in New Zealand,46</i>)

>  Do not erect a tailing pen in the same spot as last year. <i>(1919,Livestock in New Zealand,47</i>)

>  <b>HALL</b> Despite its forlorn expression, this dog is actually serving a useful purpose by being placed a the back of a temporary tailing pen. where it keeps the sheep from pushing against the weak fence. <i>(1987,Shepherd's Year,  A,26</i>)

>  <b>DREAVER</b> My favourite memories were of how pleasant it was to boil the billy in a sheltered gully at the top tailing pens at Shingly Creek, and after a day's tailing to sit back and relax for a while. <i>(1994,Catlins River Wisp Run,57</i>)



## tailing tally
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a total number of lambs docked on one property [known otherwise as a lambing percentage.]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Tailing tallies on the two places now exceed 12,000 and the woolclip is just on 500 bales. <i>(1973,Big Country of the South Island,167</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. of a normal tailing tally of about 1700 they marked less than 100. <i>(1973,Big Country of the South Island,233</i>)



## tailing yard
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a temporary yard, made of scrim or wire netting and standards, for tailing or docking lambs in a paddock.

>  <b>HALL</b> A typical tailing yard, built on the block in just half an hour. [tailing-yard] <i>(1987,Shepherd's Year,  A,29</i>)

>  It is built on Allotment No. 629, and has a frontage to the Tararu Creek Road of 31ft., with side frontages of 99ft., and adjoins the property of J. WILSON, Esq., and Brown's Tailing Yards. <i>(Apr 14, 1885,Thames Star,3</i>)

>  Portable Tailing Yards. <i>(Jun 9, 1920,Ashburton Guardian,8</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> While Ron bought sheep-dip, coils of cyclone netting for temporary tailing-yards, belt dressings for the saw bench and other essentials ... <i>(1966,Over the River,29</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> They [sheepyards] would never mean yards for a special job such as the dip yards or the temporarily erected tailing yard. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,72</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> On most sheep stations tailing yards are only temporary affairs. They are erected for the day only, and when the job is finished are pulled up, and used on the next block to be tailed. <i>(1949,High Country Days,197,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> On most sheep stations tailing yards are only temporary affairs. They are erected for the day only, and when the job is finished are pulled up, and used on the next block to be tailed. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,190</i>)

>  <b>TOMLINSON</b> We always got on well. Next [41] day we mustered down to the tailing yards. <i>(1968,Remembered Trails,40</i>)



## tailing-band
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MARSHALL</b> There was nothing in it [sc. the farm utility] except a ten-pound tin of honey, and some tailing-bands scattered on the floor. <i>(1984,Day Hemingway Died, The,141</i>) [NOTES: (Sully's Country)]



## tailing-iron
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a searing-iron used to burn through lambs tails.

>  <b>DAVIS</b> Without moving his feet, he leaned down to his right and pulled a long-handled tailing-iron from the perforated oil drum that served as a brazier. <i>(1962,Mutton on the Menu,155</i>)



## tailings
 
 <i>n.</i> the waste material removed during the processing of mineral ores [(cf TAIL v)]

>  Owing to the tailings of the sluicing claims being swept down into the Buller River the original bed with its deposits of gold has been covered over and it is now practically useless for private working. <i>(Jun 27, 1929,Evening Post,14</i>)

>  All through Central Otago huge piles of tailings could be seen that would not grow anything for hundreds of years. <i>(Mar 4, 1941,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  It saves all the gold and mercury; none can be found in the tailings by the most delicate chemical test. <i>(Dec 21, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,2</i>)

>  Tailings : The discarded portion of the ore after treatment. <i>(Sep 1999,Ohinemuri Regional History Journal,43 : 14</i>)

>  The Phoenix Syndicate's first return under the cyanide process shows that 60 tons of tailings were treated and gave 42oz 10dwt of bullion of the value of GBP3 10s per ounce. <i>(Feb 17, 1908,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  We saw on Monday four ounces of very fine gold, the result of the labour of six men in five days, who had washed the tailings left by the diggers three years and a-half ago. <i>(Oct 5, 1859,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2</i>)

>  The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings. <i>(1876,TrNZI,8/179</i>) [NOTES: Goodall Thames Gold-fields]

>  <b>BLYTH</b> <i>Tailings</i>: Useless material discarded after most of the metal has been extracted by treatment plants. <i>(1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11</i>)

>  <b>HODDER</b> ... a group of women were round the pool washing the `tailings' in tin dishes. <i>(1862,Memories of NZ Life,166</i>)

>  Kurunui Battery ... of six stampers, and one stamper specimen battery with Berdans at the end of tables to grind the tailings. <i>(1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,93</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> The goldminer in his sluicing operations, spreads out de[e-acute]bris, drift, alluvial sludge, or tailings in strata all over the plain. <i>(1873,TrNZI,6/329</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> A company formed to work these `tailings,' as the are technically termed, has been in operation some time, with payable results. <i>(1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago,140,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>`1891 The detritus</i> carried off by water from, a crushing machine, or any gold-washing apparatus.' (Brough Smyth, `Glossary of Mining Terms.') Not limited to Australia. <i>(1898,Austral English,454</i>)

>  The waste dirt and stones carried off by water from the gold-washing in some kinds of mining in Australia and New Zealand <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),403</i>)

>  <b>EVANS</b> Some of the early tailings at the Sandy Knowes ... where they show a gentle southward dip. <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,5</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> TAILINGS: all the detritus left after gold-saving. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,528,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <b>KEENE1967</b> When we were about Waipiata, and pushing up to Hamilton's station Ethel became very excited, and exclaimed, `The Tailings!' We were pushing through heavy gravel at the time. I looked about for a heap of lambs tails, the only kind of `tailings' I knew. The language of gold mining was unknown to me, and Ethel had to explain that tailings were the heaps of gravel left after the soil had been sluiced away. <i>(1967,Tang of The Bush</i>) [NOTES: (Robert McLatchie 1875-1963)]

>  <b>McARA</b> <i>Tailings</i>: The discarded portion of the ore after treatment, usually seen on the banks of the Ohinemuri River as fine, whitish, quartz sand or as muddy water in the river. The Ohinemuri River was an officially-declared sludge channel for tailings disposal. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),334</i>)

>  The tailings from stamper-batteries are as fine as sand. <i>(1896,AJHR,I-4A/6</i>)

>  The creek was named after.. Mary Boyle, who.. complained bitterly when the stream was used as a sludge channel for tailings. <i>(1959,Women of Westland,10</i>) [NOTES: From 2nd edition]

## tailor-made
 
 <i>n.</i> a manufactured cigarette (opp. to roll-your-own)

>  A boy in the big house down the road had a mother who smoked tailor-mades. <i>(Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62</i>)

>  <b>IRELAND</b> [He] invited me to sit don beside him in the shelter of the ridge and he'd show me 'how to roll a fag so you can't tell the difference with a bloody tailor-made.' <i>(1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,91</i>)

>  <b>GIBBONS</b> Since only a limited number smoked tailor-mades, collecting sets [sc. of cigarette cards] was a long business. <i>(1989,Recollections (various authors/titles),38</i>)

>  "I've even got some tailor mades," boasted Alf, producing the package. <i>(Dec 29, 1956,Weekly News,36</i>)

>  Alterations in the taxation on tobacco caused a swing back to tailor mades <i>(Sep 11, 1935,NZ Free Lance,19</i>)

>  Though there had been a big increase recently in sale of roll-your-own tobacco it did not compensate for the decline in tailor-made cigarettes.. . We have introduced mild and menthol variants because they want the options they used to get with tailor-made. <i>(Apr 28, 1992,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  Meanwhile, the contrast with TV3 was the contrast between tailor-mades and roll-your-owns. <i>(Dec 19, 1999,NZ Catholic,19</i>)

>  Give us a 'tailor-made.' <i>(1935,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,iv/36</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> (of cigarettes)

>  New Zealanders are drinking less and switching their smoking habits from tailor-made cigarettes to roll-your-owns, Statistics New Zealand says... New Zealanders were increasingly smoking cheaper roll-your-own cigarettes instead of the tailor-made variety. <i>(Nov 27, 1999,Dominion,9</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> I smoke a bit, not very much; intend later on to `roll my own' as tailor-made are rather biting. <i>(Apr 9, 1944,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1944 April 9 Letter in 1990 McKay James K. Baxter 68]



## tailpaint
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [dairying] to tag cows with waterbased paint in coded colours in order to detect and leave a record of oestrus.

>  The whole herd is tailpainted again during morning milking. <i>(Oct 2000,Waikato Times,24</i>)

>  Cows are tail-painted three weeks before mating. [tail-paint] <i>(Mar 22, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a water-based paint used to tag cows for detection of bulling at oestrus.

>  <b>EDGAR</b> The use of tail paint is a major aid to the detection of heat. <i>(1959,NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide,7</i>)

>  To identify cows which are treated or three titted, paint them on the legs with red tailpaint, stays on a lot longer than spray markers. <i>(Feb 10, 2002,RD1.com,Farm Management</i>)



## tailpainting
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the tagging of cows with waterbased paint in coded colours to aid detection and recording of oestrus.

>  Tail-painting involves applying a strip of paint along the backbone of a cow and over the point described as the 'head of the tail.' <i>(Apr 1980,NZ Dairy Exporter,49</i>)

>  Is visual selection picking up all the cows on heat, or could aids such as tail painting, recording pre-mating heats, or using a vasectomised bull with a chinball harness help? <i>(Jun 1982,NZ Dairy Exporter,2</i>)

>  Tailpainting is not used until three days before mating starts. <i>(Jul 1983,NZ Dairy Exporter,21</i>)

>  Tailpainting is an aid to heat detection. [tail-painting; tail painting] <i>(Nov 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,11</i>)



## tainter
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a pasture weed or plant that taints the flavour of milk or butter.

>  Land cress, also known as twin cress, is one of the worst milk and butter tainters. <i>(Apr 1968,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7</i>)



## tainui
 
 <i>n.</i> a North Island shrub, scarce in the wild, related to kumarahou. (See [also golden tainui](../A#also-golden-tainui))

>  <b>FEATON</b> POMADERRIS TAINUI (<i>Hector.</i>) ... Its specific name is accorded to it by the discoverer in honour of the great canoe, as that by which it is known by the Maoris. <i>(1889,Art Album NZ Flora,92</i>)

>  53 Lithograph of tainui foliage. <i>(1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16</i>)

>  <b>CHEESEMAN</b> <i>[Pomaderris apetala, Lab.] Tainui.</i> ... A common Australian plant. The Maoris assert that it sprang from the rollers or skids that were brought in the canoe `Tainui' when they first colonised New Zealand. <i>(1906,Manual NZ Flora,99</i>)

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>Pomaderris apetala (The Tainui).</i> ... Maori name <i>Tainui. </i> <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,236,1940 p. 249 ed.</i>)

>  <b>LYSNAR</b> There is a plant the Maoris call `Tainui'. It is interesting because of its association with a tradition that a specimen in the North Island sprang from a green timber used in the building of the `Tainui', a canoe which brought some of the Maori immigrants to New Zealand between five and six hundred years ago. <i>(1924,New Zealand (various authors/titles),69</i>)

>  <b>WODZICKI</b> Kirk (1896) says that the tainui (<i>Pomaderris apetala</i>) has been completely destroyed at Kawhia by goats [Kirk TrNZI 1896 XXVIII 1-27] <i>(1950,Introduced Mammals of NZ,162</i>)

>  <b>MOORE & IRWIN</b> <i>POMADERRIS APETALA, tainui</i>. An erect, rather narrow shrub growing to 5m tall. ... Known as a wild plant only in a few North Island sites, it is widespread in Tasmania and nearby parts of mainland Australia. <i>(1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,88</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [Ma.] a New Zealand-bred cultivar of wheat.

>  One further 16-acre crop of Tainui was sown during the last week of September on strong loam soil on the property of Mr Alec Stuart, Heaton Park. <i>(Sep 16, 1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,199</i>)

>  Tainui is popular in the north, but its weak straw renders it more liable to lodging .. Tainui is essentially a spring wheat. Taiaroa, which is similar to Tainui, is occasionally grown in Southland and parts of South Otago. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,75</i>)

>  <b>CRESSWELL</b> I have not seen it [the new wheat cultivar] yet, but it is a cross between Tainui and Tuscan. <i>(1951,Canterbury Tales,84</i>)

>  Tainui and Gabo are recommended for the Rangitikei-Wanganui district. <i>(Jul 1959,NZ Journal of Agriculture,27</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> <i>Pomaderris elliptica</i>

>  (And) <i>Pomaderris elliptica</i> dwarf tainui <i>(1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> kumarahou

>  <b>MATTHEWS</b> <i>Golden Tainui</i> - see <i>Pomaderris elliptica </i> <i>(1943,NZ Gardening Dictionary, The,79</i>)

>  <b>LOCKE</b> Botanical discoveries were spice to the dish. I shan't forgot the first time I saw [near Auckland] ... masses of kumarahou adorning a barren outcrop of white clay. (A cultivated variety is now sold as golden tainui.) <i>(1981,Student At The Gates,73</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> <i>Pomaderris phylicaefolia</i>

>  (And) <i>Pomaderris phylicaefolia</i> heath-like tainui <i>(1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> <i>Pomaderris elliptica</i>

>  (And) <i>Pomaderris elliptica</i> yellow tainui <i>(1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen</i>)



## Tainui
 
 <i>n.</i> an iwi

>  His ancestry is Swiss on his father's side and Tainui on his mother's. Tainui wooed him in 1992 from Auckland to Huntly's Waahi Pa, residence of the Maori Queen, to be the first GP for their pioneering health trust, Raukura Hauora O Tainui... Tainui are the iwi of the Waikato and by oral legend the descendants of the immigrants of the canoe of that name. <i>(Nov 1999,North & South,60</i>)

>  The Tainui people moved in as far back as the 14th century, followed by Europeans in the mid 1820s. <i>(Nov 2002,AA Directions,No. 54/19</i>)

>  [Hdg] Tainui faction tries to sell Defence Force land... Under the deal, Tainui would have bought the site for $975,000. <i>(Jan 12, 2001,Dominion,7</i>)

>  So, it hasn't been a matter of Tainui suddenly being deluged with undeserved riches. <i>(Apr 1998,Mana,No. 21 : 37</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (the migration canoe)

>  <b>MILLER</b> To the north of the River Mokau, the northern boundary of Taranaki, the land was occupied by four tribal groups whose ancestors came to New Zealand in the Tainui canoe. These were the Waikato, the Ngati Maniopoto, the Ngati Toa and the Ngati Raukawa. <i>(1958,Early Victorian NZ,14</i>)

>  Mokau claims the honour of being the landing-place of the "Tainui," one of the original pioneers. <i>(Aug 7, 1890,Otago Witness,36</i>)

>  Come, I will drag the Aotea and Tainui (canoes) to the shores of the sea. <i>(Mar 15, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,14</i>)

## taiore
 
 <i>n.</i>

## taipo
 
 <i>n.</i> ?taniwha

>  <b>TOWNSEND</b> There are no quadrupeds except the green lizard - which has 5 golden spots on its back - the natives are in great fear of it & call it "Syphou" - the Devil. <i>(Nov 16, 2004,Letter,9</i>) [NOTES: In <i>Absolutely Positively Wellington</i> 0/9/2004, p. 9]

>  <b>HAAST</b> On the 11th of June we started from the cave, called by the natives Te-ana-o Matuku, respecting which they tell a very interesting tale of a large ngarara, a monster in the form of an enormous lizard, which formerly lived here, and devoured all who attempted to pass. Since they have become Christians, however, they have called it by another name, Te whare Taipo (the Devil's house), probably referring the formation of the cave, of which I shall speak more fully in the geological part of my report, to supernatural agency rather than to the hand of nature. <i>(1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,50</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> We kept together, in the middle of the road, as we half expected the `taipo' to spring out of the edge of the bush and grab us at any moment. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,44</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a madman

 <i>n.</i> a) evil spirit; devil. b) in weakened use, of a naughty child: `you little taipo'. [probable Maori taipo goblin] Maori <i>taipo</i>, goblin [HWO notes:8 not in Williams 3rd edn 1871, 4th edn of 1892 (or as taepo); nor in English-Maori of 1871 at goblin, etc; 1892 English-Maori: 269 <i>Goblin</i>, n. <i>tupua;</i> kehua.<i>First appears in 1917 5th edn </i>could <i>taipo</i> have been generated in English hearers by a mishearing of<i> tipua</i>, tupua `goblin, demon' etc - of same meaning.]

>  <i>Taipo</i>, for instance, of course one knows its meaning, though it has been adopted chiefly as a name as common as `Dash' or `Nero' for New Zealand dogs; all the same the writers upon Maori superstitions seem to have no knowledge of it. Polach [sic], Dieffenbach, Nicholas, Yates, call their evil spirits <i>whiros</i> or <i>atuas</i>. Tepo, the place of darkness, is the nearest they have come to it. I think myself it is South Island Maori, often differing a little in spelling and use; and so very much the larger proportion of New Zealand literature is the literature of the North.' <i>(1896,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1896. Modern. Private Letter (May): [Morris]]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> a New Zealand word for devil, often applied by settlers to a vicious horse or as a name for a dog. There is a dangerous river, the Taipo, on the west coast. There is considerable dispute as to whether the word is true Maori or not. The Rev. T. G. Hammond of Patea says - -->`No such Maori word as taipo, meaning devil, exists. It would mean evening-tide - tai-po. Probably the early sailors introduced attached meaning of devil from the Maori saying, `Are you not afraid to travel at night?' referring to the danger of tidal rivers.' -->On the hand, Mr. Tregear says, in his `Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v. - -->`Taepo, a goblin, a spectre. C.f. <i>tae</i>, to arrive; <i>po</i>, night.' The Rev. W. Colenso says, in his pamphlet on `Nomenclature' (1883), p. 5 - -->`Taepo means to visit or come by night, - a night visitant, - a spectral thing seen in dreams, - a fancied and feared thing, or hobgoblin, of the night or darkness; and this the settlers have construed to mean the Devil! - and of course their own orthodox one.' <i>(1898,Austral English,454</i>)

>  <b>DOBSON</b> `Tae-po, the evil spirit, now comes. He comes in the form of a little pig. He often comes like that. ...' Terapuhi was still shaking with fear, but gradually he recovered and said, `Tae-po does sometimes come like that, and not do any harm, but I told you this is a bad place.' <i>Ibid.</i>96 Tae-po, an evil spirit, from the verb <i>tae</i>, to arrive, and <i>po</i>, night or darkness. An evil nocturnal visitor, incorrectly (as a rule), put as one word, Taipo, which is of course meaningless. <i>(1930,Reminiscences,95</i>)

>  <b>AYSON</b> That evening the boys held the floor, telling all sorts of Maori stories about Taipo. <i>(1937,Thomas,53</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Taipo.</i> occ.<i> taepo.</i> A vicious horse; as name for a dog: New Zealand coll.: mid-C. 19-20. Perhaps ex Maori: but see Morris. -2. Among Maoris, a s. term for a theodolite, `because it is the `land-stealing devil' (Morris). Ex <i>taepo</i>, Maori for a goblin. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,861</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> <i>mangumangu taipo </i>If she [a Maori woman] stayed on till dark she was frightened to go home alone as she was afraid of the `taipo' ... <i>Ibid.</i>20 (as a nickname c1850s-1860s) We did not get very far with our Maori, but I used to go to Maori services with Taipo (Joe Benson) and picked up quite a lot of it. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,13</i>)

>  <b>BENNETT</b> ... <i>taipo</i>, devil (from Maori <i>taepo</i> - if indeed this word was <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,93</i>)

>  <i>taipo,</i> supernatural being; goblin: used by the Maori believing it to be Pakeha, and by the Pakeha believing it to be Maori; often spelt taepo, which also is not a Maori word: so taipo is a word coined by no one knows whom... <i>taipo</i>, see the remarks following the word in list 2. There is a Maori remark that may be quoted here: Haere ra! E tama E! Mou te tai ata, moku te tai po (Farewell! O son! lit. Yours the morning tide, mine the evening tide, meaning You pass with the morning tide, as I will pass by the evening tide). The saying was often used in war, when a man saw a young relative or friend slain; and the words were often prophetic of his own fate. The meaning is quite destroyed if the last two words are run together - taipo instead of tai po: that results in the word under discussion, making the meaning: You pass on the morning tide, while I go to the devil! - naturally a modern interpretation. A Pakeha using the expression once confused that last words and made them taepa; when it meant: You pass on the morning tide, while I get over the fence. So near is the approach of the ridiculous to the sublime. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/150</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [Ma.] 1. a saddle horse that is recalcitrant or badtempered, from the Maori ''devil.'' 2. an intimidating natural feature such as a river. 3. a native weta found in caves and native bush. 4. a jagged hill of many near to the Wairarapa coast at Te Wharau and near Tinui.

## Takapuna/Takapuna class

They owe their existence to a small band of Takapuna yachtsmen who planned the first boat, with much the same idea in their minds as did George Honour when he built the first of the 14-foot square bilge boats, namely, low first cost, ease of construction, and an ever-watchful eye on speed and performance under Auckland harbour weather conditions. The yachts were originally designed for the Takapuna Boating Club but owing to their popularity from the outset the type was quickly adopted by many other yacht clubs throughout New Zealand... >  <b>DAVIS</b> The Z class, or "Zeddie" as it was affectionately known, was another class which was designed as a low cost sailing boat to get the boys into something safer than the tin canoes or derelict dinghies in which they cruised Shoal Bay. ## take
 
 <i>n.</i> [(muttonbirding)]

>  ... but this presumption has been rebutted by the admission that he had no `take', therefore he has no right to this island. <i>(Aug 1911,Gazette</i>) [NOTES: 1911 Aug Gazette in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 41]

>  <b>WILSON</b> `Take', and all references thereto, include taking, catching, killing, or pursuing, by any means or device, ... <i>(1979,Titi Heritage,171</i>) [NOTES: 1912 Regulations under Land Act in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 171]

>  <b>WILSON</b> Down the generations it had been observed that this happened about the same time each year, so the wise old chiefs set the season for the `take' for that certain time of the year which became known to the pakeha as half of March, all of April and May, allowing no trespassing on the island at any other time of the year lest the birds, refusing to nest on an island `touched' by human presence, should fly away and never return. <i>Ibid.</i> 27 Especially when the pakeha took a Maori wife; he could then share her journey to her island, and help her to `take' enough birds for their family needs. <i>Ibid.</i> 39 Some of these descendants actually visited the disputed islands and attempted to `take'. <.i>Ibid.</i> 55-56 Ever since the beginning, to `take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... to `take' also includes an `attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu. <i>Ibid.,</i> 66 In the season 1921 the Colac Bay and Riverton Maoris caught 24,000 birds, In 1922 the `take' was 14,000. <i>(1979,Titi Heritage,25</i>)



 
 (two syllables) <i>n.</i> purpose, cause [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  The academy's <i>take</i> (purpose) is about changing kids' attitudes in order to make them more employable... Rangihuna.. is passionate about the academy's real <i>take</i> and frustrated by the fixation on its sporting success. <i>(Oct 1997,North & South,77</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> Now he arranged with General Cameron to reoccupy the European land at Tataraimaka despite the repeated Maori warnings that they would regard this action as a <i>take</i>, a just cause for war. <i>Ibid.</i> <i>take</i> Root, cause <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,134</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [land-breaking] the germination and growth of a plant crop.

 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to occupy, lease or purchase land for the purpose of farming, usually as the first occupant.

## tally
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a hundred sheep.

>  .. in the happy camaderie of shed life, where toil is plenty and the little rest doubly appreciated, the general remarks revealed ambitions for 'tallies' in the afternoon. <i>(Mar 1, 1946,Ex-Pupils Budget,11</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> a hundred sheep. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,83 (i)</i>)

>  <i>(1) A hundred sheep.</i> When large mobs are counted the man counting calls out `T[ally].!' every time he gets to 100, and then starts again. Another man answers `T.' and cuts a notch in a stick. When the whole mob is counted the number of notches gives the hundreds and the odd number completes the total, which is also (2) called the t. 3. The total number of sheep shorn by each shearer in a day. 4. Hence <i>t.book,</i> in which the man who counts out, writes them down. 5. The <i>ts.</i> for the day before are written up each morning on a <i>tally board</i> kept in the shed. (C.) <i>(Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>FERNANDEZ</b> He had left the tally to Guy while he ransacked in the store for a spark plug .. <i>(1973,Tussock Fever,33</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>



 
 <i>n.</i> [meat works; cf TALLY-SPEED] (See [cut tally](../C#cut-tally))

>  <b>COLIN GORDON</b> <i>Tally</i>: You <i>cut tally</i> if you get 100 per man, and you drop so many off the tally for stags (one-ball sheep) and rams (the penises and balls of both these are cut out, and this is how one counts them; <i>pizzles</i> (undeveloped penises) are cut off wethers. <i>(May 17, 1951,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c.]

>  <b>WILSON</b> It is a mechanical business ..., slaughtering [62] by thousands, ... tinning the tongues, freezing the carcases, and tying them up in their little, white muslin shrouds, to be `tallied' and shipped to England, ... <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,61</i>) [NOTES: 1890 Feb 8 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 61-62]



 
 <i>n.</i> the amount of work done in a given time

>  The demand is even more urgent than usual as the threshing season has been fine and short straw has enabled mills to make quick work. Record tallies for a day's work have been made. <i>(Mar 22, 1911,Grey River Argus,1</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> ... any good tallies, boys. <i>(1913,Sodger Sandy's Bairn,71</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> They would work with a will for an hour or two at the outside [at gorse-cutting]. And their tally was good. <i>(1944,Shining with the Shiner,136</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> He will help our tally along if we have a bad spell; ... <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,21</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Some of the high tallies taken in the early days of the so-called `culling' operations in the great snow-grass basins of the southern Alps and elsewhere show that the shooters learned the wisdom of concentrating their fire on the leader hinds .. <i>(1953,Golden Bush, The,69,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> Stan said that a dog that chases deer on your block can cost you half your tally because it makes them more wary and difficult to catch. ...[25] I had a tally of 185 deer. <i>(1961,Good Keen Man, A,21</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [shearing] to reach a total.

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> By the end of the day Bluey had shorn 285 and I tallied 303. <i>(1991,Off the Sheep's Back,83</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> The silly creatures run and jump through [the gate], being counted or `tallied' whilst they are skipping into another enclosure. <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,243</i>)

>  Packs and loads of skins tallying over 100lbs. are far from easy to carry over vestigial tracks. <i>(Apr 8, 1953,Freedom,5</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [nf AND] spec. uses of OED vb ? (in the general sense of `counting a number of objects individually and entering the numbers up, or marking them off': e.g. tally cargo, etc) esp. by shearers, freezing workers, storemen; cf also EDD 7. A specified number or weight; in hop-picking, the number of bushels for which the picker receives a shilling. Glo Lon Sur Also vb. [(cf TALLY n1)]

>  <i>(1953,Short Stories (various authors),215</i>) [NOTES: a1927 1938 Antony Me and Gus in 1953 Short Stories 215]

>  <b>BOWEN</b> <i>(1956,Wool Away!</i>)

Another man keeps the tallies - at each call he may cut a notch in a stick or pick out a small pebble. The tally book contains a record of sheep counted during the year. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,190</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [count of prisoners]

>  Number of sheep shorn by a shearer or a gang in a day, or the number of sheep in a group. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60</i>)

>  <i>tally book</i>: The official record of what every man has shorn in each run of the day. ## tamarillo
 
 <i>n.</i> (formerly in New Zealand called tree tomato) a bright red, subtropical fruit grown on a small tree. [pl. -os]

>  The tamarillo, it seems, is still a fruit New Zealand has largely to itself, for though it is grown in private gardens around the world in warm frost-free places like California, South Africa, Asia and Africa, only here is it cultivated systematically on a commercial scale... In the 1880s, Mr D Morris, director of the Botanbical Gardens in Jamaica, sent seeds to the hill districts of India and Sri Lanka, and it was from northern India that the first seeds were sent to New Zealand, to Hay and Sons, nurserymen of Parnell in Auckland. The Hay's 1891-1892 catalogue states that the nursery then had "plants of strong and healthy appearance" for sale... The name "tamarillo" officially came into being on January 31, 1967, after New Zealand exporters decided a more romantic, exotic name was needed than "tree tomato". The strategy worked, and today tamarillo seems to have become the accepted name internationally. <i>(Jun 12, 2004,Dominion Post,E8</i>)

>  He cites the economic potential of the pepino on a par with the tamarillo. <i>(Jun 1982,Orchardist NZ,143</i>)

>  On February 1, 1967, the name tamarillo officially replaced tree tomato. <i>(Feb 1967,Orchardist NZ,23</i>)

>  The tamarillo or tree tomato, <i>Cyphomandra betacea</i> Sendt.. is a native of Brazil and Peru. <i>(Jun 1970,Orchardist NZ,149</i>)

>  <b>BURTON</b> A native of the Andean region of Peru and of southern Brazil, the tamarillo is the only one of the 30 species of its genus, Cyphomandra, to be widely known...It was from northern India that the first seeds were sent to New Zealand, in 1891, to D. Hay & Sons, nurserymen of Parnell, Auckland. <i>(1985,Delectable Fruits Cookery,145</i>)

>  Gently peel the tamarillos then carefully slide them into the simmering syrup. <i>(Sep 1999,Cuisine,No. 76 : 86</i>)

>  The Sex Kitten uses perfectly ripe tamarillos, blended with homemade vanilla sugar syrup and extra vanilla scraped from the pod, strained and frozen into ice cubes. <i>(Sep 11, 2003,Dominion Post,D1</i>)

>  Although it sounds Spanish, the name 'tamarillo' is another New Zealand invention. The former name 'tree tomato', was considered inappropriate for use overseas where people buying the fruits for the first time might expect them to taste like tomatoes. In 1967, orchardist Bill Thomson took the Maori word 'tama' added 'tillo' (taken from tomatillo, a complete unrelated Mexican fruit) and then (just to make the sound more mellifluous) he replaced 't' with an 'r'. Thus, 'tamarillo' was born. <i>(Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,58</i>)

[WWII] <i>Ibid.</i> 141 An uncultivated native of the Andes region of Peru, the tamarillo is also found wild in India, Sri Lanka and parts of South East Asia. It was from the hilly regions of northern India that New Zealand's first seeds came, introduced by the Auckland nursery of D. Hay and Sons in 1891. At first only the yellow and purple varieties were grown and it was not until the end of World War I that the now almost universal red variety was bred at Mangere, Auckland. <i>(1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,31</i>)

On the basis of <i>tomato</i>, a diminutive<i> -ill-</i> was added; then <i>tomatillo</i> was altered, in honor of a legendary Maori tribal hero, Tama-te-kapua, to <i>tamatillo</i>; and then a change to <i>tamarillo</i> was considered more euphonious. ## tangle fern
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Gleichenia dicarpa</i> (formerly <i>alpina, circinata</i>), having thin, spidery pinnae. [(often preceded by a descriptive epithet)]

>  Umbrella ferns are quite unlike any other fern. Rather than producing a typically divided frond, the midrib divides repeatedly into two, producing a bud at the end of each branch, with two new branches arising immediately below it. Lateral branching of this sort can be finite, producing a distinctive shape, as in the umbrella fern (<i>Sticherus cunninghamii</i>), or it can continue almost indefinitely, with the frond forming extensive thickets, as in the tangle fern (<i>Gleichenia dicarpa</i>). <i>(2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/72</i>)

## taniwha clause
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  If he had a niggle, it was around presentation and "MPs' use of emotive language such as the taniwha clause", which he believed many Maori would dislike. <i>(Jan 25, 2003,Dominion Post,A1</i>)

>  The perfect symbol for all this is the Meremere taniwha. This one-eyed spirit stopped work on a new highway.. and gave National leader Bill English a new slogan. A reference to the Treaty in new legislation became the "taniwha clause" - a phrase coated in political poison... Historian Michael King says the issue "has nothing to do with the literal existence of non-existence of taniwha. Taniwha are a metaphorical way of saying that place is either dangerous or has special spiritual or historical significance. The way Maori signified that was by talking about taniwha or guardian to make poeople respect it and to explain the fact that sometimes people disppeared or drown or whatever, in those places". <i>(Feb 2, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C5</i>)

 <i>adj.</i>



 
 <i>adj.</i> [also tapu'd] (See [tabooed](../T#tabooed))

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> In the afternoon we were told that a large party was on their way to this place, for the purpose of stripping us ... Tikoki had stripped an Englishman on the opposite side yesterday ... out of revenge for some property of his, which had been stolen out of a <i>tapu</i>ed house ... <i>(Jan 29, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The</i>) [NOTES: 1827 Jan 29 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 41]

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> The canoe was <i>Tapu'</i>d, having conveyed the body of Hengi ... to his former place. <i>(Jan 18, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,1961 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1832 Jan 18 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 220]

>  <b>YATE</b> A man who has touched a very young child, or has approached a corpse, or has rendered the last sad offices of friendship for a friend, is strictly tapued for several days; and is not allowed to touch food with his hands, nor in any way to feed himself, but by picking up his sustenance from the ground with his lips and teeth. <i>(1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),85</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> ... such would have been Caddell's fate, had he not ran up to a chief ... who happened accidentally to be tapued at the time, and, catching hold of his garment, was saved in consequence; ... <i>Ibid.</i>1/67 She politely welcomed us, as we marched through her plantation of Indian corn and kumeras [a-acute], which were nearly ripe and in fine condition : unfortunately for us, the place was strictly tapued, or prohibited from being touched by any person, until the following harvest; ..<i>Ibid.</i>1/141 The whole of the prepared flax was tapued [a-acute], and of course safe from depredation. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/52</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> When a place is to be <i>tapued</i>, the intimation is announced to all whom it may concern (or not) by a <i>raoui</i> or grotesque carving in wood, painted with the usual red earth, which is found in certain districts, and is baked after the native method. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/276</i>)

>  <b>MAJORIBANKS</b> The `tapu' or tabboo is a ceremony common to New Zealand, along with all the other South Sea Islands. The power of `tapuing' seems to be vested in the principal chief alone, and may be considered the most important bulwark of his authority. This ceremony [90] renders every object, either animate or inanimate, sacred, or not to be approached, so that no person can enter tapued ground, nor touch a tapued person. Every girl promised in marriage is tapued, and married women also, until chastised by their husbands, when the `tapu' ceases, and they are then free to any one who can catch them, a remarkably good plan for securing the affections of the husband, and relieving the sex from some of those periodical chastisements in which some of the husbands in this country are so apt to indulge. Favourite pigs, canoes, and muskets are sometimes tabooed; burial ground is always tabbooed, and so is also a chief's head. <i>(1844,Travels in NZ,89</i>)

>  ... a principal chief, who it seems was <i>tapued</i>, or rendered sacred for the time, was knocked down and beaten by one of the Maori police, ... <i>(May 17, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6</i>)

>  <b>MUNDY</b> The tapued resting place of departed chieftains. <i>(1852,Our Antipodes,284,1855 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [check pagination with 1852 edn]]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> ... at certain seasons places where shell-fish abounded were tapued. <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/153</i>)

>  <b>MANING</b> In some cases he would be fed by another person, who ... would manage to do it without touching the<i> tapu'd</i> individual; ... <i>Ibid.</i> (viii) 136 ... I myself once got <i>tapu'd </i>with this same horrible ... style of <i>tapu?</i> <i>(1863,Old New Zealand,(viii) 134</i>)

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> About two hours after she retired to a house, in which had been hung up a tapued gun; this she loaded, and ... discharged it. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,63</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE</b> Some of the settlers had unwittingly caused trouble by cutting down `tapued' trees to build boats. <i>(1930,NZ Memories,80</i>)

>  <b>CURR</b> [see introd. cits] No wonder the subject is tabooed (or tapued) here [in Wellington]. <i>(1856,Waste Lands of Wellington, The,5</i>)

>  He walked a short distance to a tapu'd place and with the utmost unconcern brought me the head wrapped in a dirty bloody native mat. <i>(1999,James Preece Missionary Papers,23</i>) [NOTES: From <i>The Missionary Register</i> 1838]

>  The carrying of a road for the Company through a piece of tapued ground is still under consideration, and only requires the exercise of a little patience and pertinacity to secure it. <i>(Feb 16, 1870,Taranaki Herald,8</i>)

## tar
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <i>tar</i>: Stockholm tar was once used as an antiseptic sealer on cuts, and although this has been generally replaced by improved antiseptics and special powders against flies, these new substances are still referred to as `tar'.  <i>v.</i>

<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to apply tar to a sheep afflicted with shearing wounds or fly-strike.

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out `T., boy, t. on the leg', and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a <i>t.stick</i> and puts it back in the <i>t. pot.</i> Patterson writes of `The tar boy, the cook, and the slushy, The sweeper that swept the board', but I do not think a tarboy was ever employed specially in New Zealand sheds. (C.) <i>(Dec 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> TAR: In earlier days a pot of Stockholm tar was kept in shearing sheds. If sheep were cut during shearing, the cut was dabbed with tar. >  <b>SCRYMGEOUR</b> exclam. (shearers') Proceeding just fair, but with their regularity that follows a shearer getting his back used to the arduous job, the advancement went on but with a different and a rougher cut than was usual. More frequently application of the loppies galloping down the board, to the ever increasing cry of `Tar'. <b>3</b> <i>n.</i> shortened form of tar-seal [ca?1939 A Havelock rhyme about a child who persisted in riding his tricycle on the newly-sealed main road Robin rode on the Havelock road,/ A motorist came from afar;/ Jim Lovell took his shovel and broom/ And scraped him off the tar.]

## tattoo
 
 <i>v.</i> [also tatu]

>  "It is generally supposed Te Kooti has Ririrangi tattooed up in his breast; but this is quite wrong, as cer[t]ified by those who have known him from childhood up to the fall of ngatapa, and whose information is of the most reliable kind. <i>(Oct 14, 1869,West Coast Times,3</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> . [aka tatu, tatto; derived from Polynesian dialects, was introduced to general English after the publication of Cook's Voyages (so Morris), and used by English speakers in New Zealand as the usual word for (applying) the Maori <i>moko</i> n `tattooing (on face or body)'] (See [moko](../M#moko))

>  Both sexes paint their bodys. <i>Tattow </i>as it is called in their language. [check context and reference: ??Maori] <i>(Jul 1769,Cook's Journals,1/125,1955 ed.</i>)

>  ... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics. <i>(Nov 1769,Cook's Journals,1/213</i>)

>  `They have a custom of staining their bodies ... which they call <i>Tattowing</i>. They prick the skin, so as just not to fetch blood, with a small instrument, something in the form of a hoe. ... <i>(1773,Hawkesworth's Voyages,2/191</i>) [NOTES: >1773. `Hawkesworth's Voyages' (Cook's First Voyage; at Tahiti, 1769), vol. ii. p. 191:]

>  <b>LEDYARD</b> They are very curiuosly tatowed or punctuated in different parts of the body, particularly in the face. The food of the New-Zealanders is chiefly fish, ... <i>(Feb 1777,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1777 Feb in 1783 Ledyard Journal (1963) 14]

>  <b>FORSTER</b> ... the custom of tattowing the faces in spirals and Various scrolls, which prevails in New-Zeeland .... <i>(1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,271</i>)

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> The chisel was constantly dipped in a [172] liquid made of soot from a particular tree, and afterwards mixed with water, which communicates the blackness or, as they call it, the amoko (<i>moko</i>). I observed proud flesh rising in some part of the breech which had been cut almost one month before. The operation is too painful to bear the whole tattooing at one time. They appear to be several years before they are perfectly tattooed. <i>(1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,171,1932 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McCRAE</b> ... as a gratifying memorial of his victory, [he] had got his nose tattooed afresh. <i>(1820,Journal,19,1928 ed.</i>)

## tauhinu
 
 <i>n.</i> [tawini, tawhina]



 
 <i>n.</i> a small shrub, the New Zealand cottonwood. [Maori] [Tawini, tawhine, tawhina, et al; the main application in NZ English is to the <i>Cassinia</i> sp., a troublesome weed of central New Zealand. Its eradication generates word-combinations: <i>tauhinu-contract, tauhinu-pulling, tauhinu-rash, to pull tauhinu</i>. =yellow scrub (?Golden tauhinu)]

## tauiwi
 
 <i>adj.</i> not Maori, foreign [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  She asked if she could move to the "tauiwi" group, where she would have a better chance of improving her Maori language skills. <i>(Aug 29, 1998,Dominion,8</i>)

 <i>n.</i> outsider, foreigner, non-Maori

>  Here, after all, was the woman who habitually refers to non-Maori New Zealanders as tau iwi, which, depending on the inflection of translation, means foreigner. <i>(Sep 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18</i>)

>  `Pakeha' is a word that seems to be bugging many New Zealanders. Perhaps this is the reason why the Royal Commission on Social Policy in its booklet dealing with the Treaty of Waitangi uses the word `Tauiwi' instead of `Pakeha'. For example a section of the booklet is headed `Partnership between Maori and Tauiwi'. Tauiwi, according to the booklet's glossary, means `later settlers from another country'. A Dictionary of the Maori Language ... gives `strange tribe, foreign race' as the meaning of Tauiwi. As a New Zealander born and bred in this country I was disturbed at the unceremonious use of a word which seems to make me some sort of foreigner in my own land. ... On phoning the commission's office I was informed that despite considerable unease over the use of Tauiwi in the treaty booklet staff were told that it had to be used. I was also informed that the use of Tauiwi instead of Pakeha had been discontinued. <i>(Jun 6, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,11</i>)

>  Here he was overwhelmed by a distinctly unappreciative din from his fellow indigenes and tau iwi alike. <i>(Aug 4, 2004,Dominion Post,A2</i>)

>  Just a couple of years back, one of the Prime Minister's colleagues.. insultingly classified non-Maori New Zealanders are [sic] foreigners in their own land by referring to them as "tauiwi". <i>(Jun 4, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A8</i>)

## taupata
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  She [sc. Alison Gray] proved the point in a 1981 study, co-authored with Rosemary Barrington, called The Smith Women. This identified our tidy suburban homes, clipped taupata hedges, flower beds in well-cut lawns. <i>(Sep 7, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20</i>)

>  <b>JACKSON</b> An arthritic taupata hedge sheltered it from the sea, though from the sunporch - which became my room - you could see the ocean ... <i>(1988,Rainshadow,98</i>)

>  This summer, as last year, rain was so plentiful in parts of Wellington that taupata berries have swollen up like juicy blueberries. <i>(Mar 8, 2003,Dominion Post,F15</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) a shrub of the coprosma family often used as a hedge plant; <i>Coprosma repens</i> [ORIGIN: Maori, also called plumber's curse. [Ma. <b>taupata</b> coastal shrub (<i>coprosma repens</i>) cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 251.]

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Taupata, <i>Col[enso]. Coprosma retusa. </i> <i>(1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> The Putiritiri, of the same order [as Karamu, coprosma sp.], is a beautiful tree with a small leaf, and also the Taupata, which having a fine bright leaf is a very ornamental tree ... <i>(1868,Past and Present of NZ,225</i>)

>  .. the curious red fruit of the Titoki, or Titongi, (<i>Alectryon excelsum</i>); the fruit .. of several species of <i>Coprosma</i>, - particlularly the Karamu (<i>C. lucida</i>), and (<i>C. robusta</i>), of the Papaauma (<i>C. grandifolia</i>), and of the two littoral species, Taupata (<i>C. retusa</i>), and Tataraheke (<i>C. acerosa</i>) ... <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/III/31</i>) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>C[oprosma retusa]</i> is much used for hedges in Wellington and Melbourne. In the former place it is generally known as <i>taupata</i> (sometimes <i>naupata</i>); in the latter it is called the <i>looking-glass</i> plant. <i>Ibid</i>. 395 <i>Coprosma [retusa] (The Taupata)</i> .. Maori names, <i>Taupata</i> and <i>Naupata. (Coprosma Baueri)</i>. [The true <i>C. Baueri</i> is a native of Norfolk Island]. <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,392,1940 p. 420 (p. 423) ed.</i>)

>  The plant which is dominant and chiefly gives character to these island shrubberies is <i>Coprosma Baueri</i>, commonly known as the taupata. <i>(1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/185</i>) [NOTES: (Sladden)]

>  <i>taupata</i>, a tree (Coprosma retusa), with dark green leaves shining as if varnished; much used for hedges, cutting well till in the course of years it grows too woody. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> [Maori glossary] <i>taupata</i> Tree (<i>Coprosma</i> retusa) <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,302</i>)

>  <b>HILLIARD</b> And there's the lights on the leaves of the <i>taupata</i>, and on the<i> tutu</i> trees over the creek where the cows can't get at them. <i>(1960,Maori Girl,215</i>)

>  <b>DURRELL</b> <i>(1966,Two in the Bush,68</i>)

>  <b>MANTELL</b> There were trees growing thick there - ngaio, taupata, native fuchsia. <i>(1980,Murder and Chips,34</i>)

>  Between it and the front hedge (taupata) there were eight large trees. <i>(1985,Women's Work,114</i>) [NOTES: (Roche Structurally Sound)]

>  <i>taupata n</i>. NZ shrub of the coprosma family, widely used for shelter-fences. [M] <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,787</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>DAWSON</b> In the North Island particularly, prostrate shrubs of the shiny-leaved taupata (<i>Coprosma repens</i>), known as the `looking glass plant' in California where it is cultivated) are often prominent. <i>(1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,155</i>)

>  <b>LEE & KENDALL</b> T|ao r|eka r|eka, s. A slave. <i>(1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207</i>)

>  Taupata has thick oval-shaped leaves with an almost plastic feel to them .. In the garden, where conditions are less harsh than the beach, the leaves grow broader and flatter, and taupata can be easily grown and pruned to a hedge eight metres tall. <i>(Feb 11, 2006,Dominion Post,20,Indulgence ed.</i>)

>  The vicar had observed that the taupata needed trimming to clear the harbour view. <i>(Apr 19, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27</i>)

>  Taupata (Coprosma repens) is one of the commonest native shrubs in this part of the country, and it seems to evoke a love or hate reaction. <i>(Mar 8, 2003,Dominion Post,F15</i>)

'he wrote,' when roasted and ground have a splendid coffee aroma and when made into coffee the results seem to be thoroughly satisfactory.' <i>(1995,Which Coastal Plant?,9</i>)

## taura here
 
 <i>n.</i> urban grouping within an iwi [ORIGIN: Maori, (from tpk.govt.nz) Due to the large population and land area, TRAION has implemented Takiwa (natural geographical groupings) to assist with the management of issues relating to the population and the marae that fall into the Ngapuhi catchment area. There are also two Taurahere (urban groupings) since 80% of the tribe live outside the traditional Ngapuhi boundaries (40% in Auckland alone). The TRAION structure is grassroots focussed with the marae and all who whakapapa to these marae being the main drivers for the vision, and for the tribal immortality of Ngapuhi.]

>  The report said the onus to build a positive relationship with taurahere organisations was on council. ... He wanted the term tuarahere better defined. <i>(Nov 3, 2005,Horowhenua Mail,5</i>) [NOTES: -]

## Tauranga disease
 
 <i>n.</i> bush sickness

>  <i>tauranga n</i> -s [Maori]<i> NewZeal </i>: BUSH SICKNESS <i>(1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2344</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a potentially fatal disease of sheep, caused by cobalt deficiency. [aka Tauranga sickness]

>  At the time of my visit the deaths had ceased for this year, and I was unable to obtain lambs for post-mortem examination that had died of the 'Tauranga disease.' <i>(Nov 1891,NZ Farmer,447</i>)

>  <b>DEPT OFLANDS & SURVEY</b> This wasting disease or condition in ruminant stock was known locally by several names: 'Tauranga disease' (because it was first reported from there in 1893 and again in 1897) ... <i>(1975,Prosperity from Pumice Land,7</i>)

>  During the 1890s, stock inspectors and veterinary reports described a condition known as 'bush disease' in cattle and 'Tauranga disease' in sheep. <i>(Mar 1979,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60</i>)

>  Take for instance the `Tauranga sheep-disease,' as it is called: professors of different colleges are sent for, to investigate it ... <i>(1892,TrNZI,24/626</i>)

>  The study of the deficiency disease for many years known as `bush sickness', `bush disease', `Tauranga disease', or `the skinnies', and now definitely and officially known as `iron starvation' was commenced by the writer in 1910. <i>Ibid.</i> 538 ) Gilruth (3) 1899 recorded his examination of a few cases of `Tauranga or Bush Sickness' [in 1899, Annual Report, Dept of Agriculture, 87]. <i>(1928,TrNZI,58/537</i>) [NOTES: Aston]

>  ".. Some experiments in contagious mammitis have yet to be done, and the 'Bush['] or 'Tauranga' disease, which affects a considerable area of country near Rotorua, still remains to be coped with." <i>(Jan 11, 1909,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  [Hdg] "Tauranga" or "Bush Disease". This peculiar wasting disease, which is confined to the tract of land lying in the vicinity of Tauranga, and extending from there to Rotorua and Lichfield, was made the subject of an investigation by Mr. Park three years ago... It appears that both sheep and cattle will do well and put on condition for the first few months after being placed on this diseased country, but as time goes on a gradual wasting sets in, which ends in death if they are not removed to another district. <i>(1899,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VII/87</i>)

>  It would seem that to deal thoroughly with the matter much more time and research will have to be given to it, than the examination of a few sheep or lambs can accomplish, though done by as able an expert as Professor Thomas; whose instructions, as to parasitical disease, seem to have been carried out as well as opportunity allowed, and yet disclosed nothing specially distinct in the Tauranga disease. <i>(Apr 15, 1891,Bay of Plenty Times,2</i>)



## Tauranga/Tauranga class

## taurekareka

>  <b>BUCK</b> <i>(1949,Coming of the Maori, The,3/338</i>)

>  <b>HULME</b> Aue, I know you recall. You lost your good temper and yelled at me all kinds of rude names and swearing, taureka and sloven, 'pokokohua and bitch. <i>(1986,Te Kaihau,115</i>) [NOTES: [spg taureka]]

 <i>exclam.</i>

>  Heeding Captain William Cargill's advice to "settle on the tens", they took up the suburban 10-acre allotments along the harbour or in areas such as North East Valley, Wakari and Andersons Bay. <i>(Apr 1998,North & South,78</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a ball-bouncing game

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Ball-bouncing games have come into their own on the asphalt playgrounds of modern schools and are played in many schools throughout the country. There is no evidence of such games before 1900, but a number of instances between 1900 and 1920 are recorded. The games were known as Fives, Tens, Sevens, and Walls and have been recorded more often since under the names O'Leary or Sevens. Before 1920 there is only one report of the game being played with a rhyme, and this was a rhyme more often used in skipping. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,273</i>)

## tenth
 
 <i>n.</i> [usually tenths]

>  As it was a test suit by which their right to all the other sections was to be determined, their claim to the 'tenths' has passed away. <i>(1877,NZ Parliamentary Debates,517</i>)

>  The matter is still further complicated by the stipulation attached to the various trusts, such as the Kemp Trust, and the Native tenths, from which some of the medical officers are paid. <i>(May 16, 1913,Poverty Bay Herald,8</i>)

>  Attempts to place a contemporary value on the nearly four million acres Ngai Tahu should have owned had the Crown set aside the promised "tenth" of all land sold is extraordinarily difficult. <i>(Nov 1993,North & South,60</i>)

>  The Whakarewa Grant was part of what was called the `tenth', a term coined by the New Zealand Company for land it reserved for Maori people. The principle of the tenths was conveyed in the instructions from the New Zealand Company in 1839 to its principal agent, Colonel William Wakefield, before he set out for New Zealand. In `every purchase of land from the natives ... a proportion of the territory ceded will be reserved by the Company and held in trust by them for the future benefit of the chief families of the tribe ... `You will explain that after English immigration and settlement a tenth of the land will be far more valuable than the whole was before'. ... To Alexander MacKay, commissioner of Native Lands, writing in 1872, the tenths `guarded the natives that common failing of all Aboriginal races, want of foresight, and it secured them from the dangers to which colonisation exposed them'. In short, land was a better asset for the Maoris than cash. In Nelson, the `tenth' comprised a total of 15,000 acres of land, involving a mix of urban and rural land in Nelson, Motueka, and Golden Bay. Most of that land remains in Maori ownership and today is managed by an incorporation. The Whakarewa land - the most valuable area of the tenth - has however been subverted from the control of the ... <i>(Jul 1986,New Outlook,28</i>)

>  [Colonel William Wakefield] set about negotiating the purchase of some 160,000 acres and in Septmeber 1839 a deed of purpose, written in English, was signed by 16 local chiefs. It provided that one tenth of the land purchased would be reserved for the Maori owners of the Land... No proper explanation was given to Maori of the 'tenths' reserve scheme, nor were they made aware that the deed of purchase made no provision for the retention by Maori of their pa, cultivations, and burial grounds. <i>(Jun 2003,Wel-com (Wellington),13</i>)

>  They claim that they are descended from one of the chiefs who sold the land around Port Nicholson to Col. Wakefield in the early days of settlement, and that they are entitled to their share of what are known as the Wellington tenths. <i>(Sep 6, 1899,Evening Post,5</i>)

>  Fortunately for some of the Maoris of the Porirua and Hutt districts they are in receipt of small yearly sums from the proceeds of their interests in the Nelson and Wellington "tenths" and the rents of small pieces of land. <i>(Nov 2, 1906,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  Of the 110,000 acres so measured one tenth part is to be reserved for the use or benefit of the aborigines, according to the original plan of sale proposed by the New Zealand company; and the lands for the aborigines shall be selected by lot, as provided for by the same plan of sale. <i>(Dec 10, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1</i>)

>  [The Maori reserves] comprise, for example, the Wellington, Nelson, and Motueka "tenths", being a tenth part of the land reserved for the Maoris by the New Zealand Company. <i>(1955,NZ Parliamentary Debates,307/2947</i>)

## tenure review
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) an exchange of some Crown-leased land for conservation purposes, for freehold title to the remainder of a leased property.

>  It's called "tenure review", an unremarkable term for a remarkable transformation now taking place in our legendary South Island high country. In exchange for giving up the scenic and uneconomic parts of their land for a massive conservation estate, pastoral lease holders get freehold title to the rest of their property. [18] Currently, the main way of achieving it [sc. taking land for the conservation estate]is known as tenure review; a huge land swap inside the pastoral leases that make up 20 percent of the South Island and 10 percent of New Zealand. <i>(Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16</i>)

>  When Jim Morris of Ben Avon Station entered tenure review, he did it with an open mind, prepared to move with the times and embrace the consequences. <i>(Jun 2007,Conservation Action,17</i>)

>  High-country farmers are quietly opting for tenure review because many are likely to become wealthy from what is [7] one of the best real estate deals in New Zealand in the last 50 years... I suspect that history will judge tenure review as not such a great idea for farmning or the public... What should have happened is a careful review of the pastoral lease system to maintain this unique form of land tenure, with adjustments to assist farmers to diversify and to protect uneconomic land. <i>(Jul 26, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6</i>)

>  <b>Relph</b> After six years about two-thirds of the 300 pastoral leases in the South Island have passed through or are undergoing tenure review. <i>(2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,144</i>)

>  Tenure review is a voluntary process for owners of high-country leases who may trade off areas of high conservation value to the conservation estate in return for freeholding the rest of their farms. <i>(Oct 9, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17</i>)
