## terms
 
 <i>n.</i> have/run sheep on terms [see Acland quotation below (cf thirds; even terms) [check index at ON]

>  Letters to Godley (J. Hamilton, Christchurch) Russell is giving up his sheep on terms at the Upper Station. <i>(1855,Canterbury Papers,2/250</i>)

>  <b>FITTON</b> I may here explain the ... custom of placing out capital under the care of an experienced manager, to be invested in sheep, or occasionally in cattle also. This is a well-known arrangement in the colonies, under the name of `keeping stock on terms', and is very general, and ... the most advisable [230] plan for persons who cannot conveniently reside on a station of their own at a distance from a town <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),229</i>)

>  <b>FITTON</b> I may here explain the ... custom of placing out capital under the care of an experienced manager, to be invested in sheep, or occasionally in cattle also. This is a well-known arrangement in the colonies, under the name of `keeping stock on terms', and is very general, and ... the most advisable [230] plan for persons who cannot conveniently reside on a station of their own at a distance from a town <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),229</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep and put them out on terms. I will explain to you what this means. I can buy a thousand ewes ..., these I should place in charge of a squatter whose run is not fully stocked ... This person would take my sheep for either three, ... or more years, ... and would allow me yearly <i>2s. 6d.</i> per head in lieu of wool. This would give me <i>2s. 6d</i>. as the yearly interest on <i>25s. Besides this he would allow me 40 per cent. per annum of increase, ...; moreover, the increase would return me 2s. 6d.</i> per head wool money as soon a they became sheep. At the end of the term, my sheep would be returned to me as per agreement, ... sheep of the same age as [any who have died] would have been will be returned in their place. <i>(Oct 2, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,4/36</i>)

>  [My sheep] are on for one year less 40% less 3% deaths, 2/6 wool money. ... Sheep on terms are not what they used to be ... <i>(Mar 25, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,170,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>DUNCAN</b> [In 1862] Mr Switzer bought some few hundred sheep ... which were `running on terms' with Mr Rees. <i>(1888,Wakatipians,64</i>)

>  <i>Sheep on terms</i>. A favourite investment in the fifties and sixties. A man bought ewes and handed them over to a runholder whose run was understocked and who had not money to buy sheep. The runholder allowed the owner of the ewes 2s 6d a head a year for their wool and marked 40 per cent. of lambs for the owner as well; or they shared the increase equally. When the ewe lambs became old enough they were bred from as well, so that by the end of the time arranged (anything from three to seven years) the owner had a much larger mob to sell than he had started with. The practice was so much in vogue that in 1863 C.M. Ollivier published a pamphlet computing the interest and profit of <i>s. o. t.</i> at the various lengths of time. The last of such agreements at Horsley Down ran out in 1870 (H. D. letter book) and these are the latest I have found any record of. `I must confess to be fairly puzzled to know what to do with the money you have sent me. Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep put them out on terms.' --[Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 37, where there is a good description of the business too long to quote. <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <i>Sheep on terms</i>. A favourite investment in the fifties and sixties. A man bought ewes and handed them over to a runholder whose run was understocked and who had not money to buy sheep. The runholder allowed the owner of the ewes 2s 6d a head a year for their wool and marked 40 per cent. of lambs for the owner as well; or they shared the increase equally. When the ewe lambs became old enough they were bred from as well, so that by the end of the time arranged (anything from three to seven years) the owner had a much larger mob to sell than he had started with. The practice was so much in vogue that in 1863 C.M. Ollivier published a pamphlet computing the interest and profit of <i>s. o. t.</i> at the various lengths of time. The last of such agreements at Horsley Down ran out in 1870 (H. D. letter book) and these are the latest I have found any record of. `I must confess to be fairly puzzled to know what to do with the money you have sent me. Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep put them out on terms.' --[Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 37, where there is a good description of the business too long to quote. <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Jim ... evidently must have had some money for he owned sheep which Ritchie kept for him `on terms', that is Ritchie fed and looked after Jim's sheep, keeping half the wool and the [?check] natural increase in return [ca1860s-1870s]. <i>(1952,Chatham Islands,146</i>)

## tern
 
 <i>n.</i> a seabird related to the gull, having a slender body, long wings, and graceful flight. [check white-fronted, black-fronted, Antarctic, caspian; sea-swallow, tara, kahawai-bird]

>  <b>FORSTER</b> Saw common Albatrosses, ... & some affirmed to have seen Eggbirds or Terns. [ed. fn] Not specifically identifiable but perhaps the White-fronted Tern <i>Sterna striata</i> (Gmelin, 1789). <i>Ibid.</i> 2/289 <i>Capt Furneaux </i>dined with us & I described a new <i>Owl</i> & a new <i>Tern</i>, the former of which was drawn by George. [ed. fn] <i>Sterna antarctica</i> of <i>Descr. Anim</i>., p.107. Now the Black-fronted Tern <i>Chlidonias hybrida albostriatus</i> (Gray, 1845). <i>(Mar 25, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/237</i>)

>  <b>FORSTER</b> We saw ... [in s. Indian Ocean] a single tern (<i>sterna</i>) or as the seamen call it an egg-bird, which had a forked tail. <i>(1777,Voyage Round the World,1/113</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> Among these may be noticed the albatross, the molimawk, the Cape pigeon, and several varieties of tern and petrel. The Cape pigeon, which is a beautifully marked black and white bird about the size of a wood pigeon, will follow the vessel to the end of the voyage. <i>(1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,8</i>)

>  <b>NATUSCH</b> Family STERNIDAE (terns). The graceful white-fronted tern <i>(Sterna striata, ... )</i> is seen in all New Zealand bays ... The somewhat stumpier black-fronted tern (<i>Chlidonias hybrida albostriatus, </i>... ) is common on South Island shingle flats ... The large Caspian tern (<i>Hydroprogne caspia</i>, ... ) is a large tern that includes New Zealand ... in its world-wide breeding range ... The rarest tern breeding in New Zealand is the fairy tern <i>(Sterna nereis,) </i>reported from Lake Ellesmere in 1944, and breeding also, sparingly, in Northland and a few other places. <i>(1967,Animals of NZ, The,267</i>)

 <i>v.</i>

 <i>n.</i> a horizontal shelf on the side of a hill, or sloping ground [cf. terrace bottom, terrace workings]

>  <b>FORSTER</b> The Scenery of the country was bold & worthy of the Pencil of a <i>Salvator Rosa</i>, all the Sides of hills were steep, rocky, & on all the little slopes & small terrasses or Settlements covered with fine shrubs, of various kinds; we saw here a great many <i>Palmtrees,</i> [ed. fn Cordyline sp.] of the same kind as had been found on April Ye 24th. <i>(Apr 27, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/267</i>)

>  [The Rangitata Valley bottom] consisted of a large swamp from which arose terrace after terrace up the mountains. ... >  <b>BUTLER</b> I had to cross the Waimakiriri just after a fresh, ... and I assure you I did not like it. ## terrace bottom
 
 <i>n.</i> [Cf. bottom n]

>  ".. The tunnel is just on the border line, and Mr Morgan is of the opinion that the tunnel is leaving the terrace bottom and coming into wash." <i>(Nov 13, 1883,Grey River Argus,2</i>)

>  The underlying brown terrace bottom, which is now within 18 inches of the black laths, is more like soft sandstone than the usual gravel conglomerate. <i>(Apr 4, 1916,Grey River Argus,4</i>)

>  Cumming's claim, adjoining the latter company, is worked by three shifts, night and day, and maintains a very high reputation among those contributing our golden harvest. It is one which has a long time yet in store ere the necessity will arise to sink for the fifth or terrace bottom. <i>(Feb 20, 1871,West Coast Times,2</i>)

>  Nature of country sunk through between second and third bottoms, fine gravel with terrace bottom, watery drift and sandy clay, coarse light gravel, and admixture of clay and gravel. <i>(Dec 7, 1899,Otago Witness,19</i>)

>  They intend sinking for the terrace bottom, which they expect to reach at about 200 feet. <i>(Aug 13, 1867,West Coast Times,4</i>)

## Territorial
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>INGRAM</b> Those of us who had received training as Territorials were asked to-day whether we would care for stripes. <i>(Jan 9, 1917,Anzac Diary,10,1987 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> The Defence Act of 1909 created The <i>Territorial Force; ... </i> <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/384</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>Territorials</i>: The army RESERVES, weekend warriors, not to mention a fortnight in January. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,102</i>)

>  <b>PUGSLEY</b> The organisation had been outlined by Field Marshal Lord Kitchener on a visit to New Zealand in 1910. All New Zealanders from the ages of 14 to 30 years were liable for part-time military training. Boys from 14 to 18 years served in the senior cadets, and young men from 18 to 25 years served as Territorial soldiers with the regionally affiliated regiments and battalions - hence the name `Territorial'. Service in the reserve was a requirement from the age of 25 to 30, but legislation allowed for this service to be extended up to the age of 55 years in the case of a national emergency. The same legislation allowed the Territorial Force to be mobilised by proclamation for service in New Zealand, and Section 26 (1) of the 1909 Defence Act made provision for members of the Territorial Force to volunteer for special service outside New Zealand. <i>(1984,Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story,38</i>)

## terror
 
 <i>n.</i> used for anything surprisingly distinctive or outstanding, either good or bad; a great one for, usu. humorous [thus different in sense or application from P8: something large or forbidding of its kind; something allegedly difficult to handle: contrast <i>Holy Terror</i> or <i>Terror</i>]

>  Owing to the inclemency of the weather - the preceding night being "a terror" for wind and rain, when the wind blew as "'twad blawn its last," and the rain fell in torrents, and Friday being also a cold and stormy day (the dark clouds began to disperse and there was a gleam of sunshine about 4 o'clock) - the attendance was not so large as was anticipated. <i>(Nov 29, 1878,Clutha Leader,6</i>)

>  The son of our next-door neighbour is of an inquisitive turn of mind (writes "Marcia"), and, as his father, says, it "a terror for finding out things," Mr. M_____ tries to get even with the small questioning son sometimes, but doesn't always manage it. <i>(Jun 8, 1910,Colonist (Nelson),1</i>)

>  14 Billy is one of those players who get right into the thick of it, and is a terror for work. <i>(Sep 9, 1922,Evening Post,14</i>)

>  There was a young farmer of Kent, / Such a terror for using strong scent / That he sprayed himself over / With otto de clover, / And bees chased him wherever he went. <i>(Jul 14, 1937,Evening Post,10</i>)

>  <b>KERSHAW</b> .. the roads were terrors, the lake was a terror, some of the women were terrors .. Terror is a New Zealand adjective. Shilling knives are advertised as `perfect terrors'. You can't go far wrong if you call a thing a terror. <i>(1886,Colonial Facts and Fictions,266</i>)

>  <b>DAVIN</b> Your uncle was a terror for the drink after you went away. <i>(1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,24</i>)

>  COMMENT: `I'm a terror for my veges'. <i>(1961,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: programme about Christmas foods]

>  [The plough] would quite often overturn. Having done so, it was a terror of a thing to get upright again. <i>(Oct 30, 1963,Weekly News,[farming page]</i>)

## tewhatewha
 
 <i>n.</i> a long axe-like Maori weapon, usually of wood and having both blade and sharpened handle. [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  The carved weapons of the Maori on which he lavished so much of his artistic skill are well represented in stone and bone mere, taiaha, and tewhatewha. <i>(Oct 16, 1925,Evening Post,9</i>)

>  Boys were taught at a very tender age the use of weapons when they indulged in mock battles in which reeds and flax stems were used in practising movements they would later use in earnest when the taiaha and tewhatewha were in their hands. <i>(Apr 1958,Te Ao Hou,22: 45</i>)

>  The <i>tewhatewha</i>, or <i>paiaka</i>, was used in somewhat similar fashion to the <i>taiaha. </i> <i>(1894,TrNZI,26/441</i>)

>  <i>tewhatewha,</i> a weapon with a terminal broad semi-crescent of one side, the other end sharpened for thrusting, the lower side of the crescent pierced with a hole for attachment of a small tuft of feathers, such as pigeon-feathers, the weapon being largely used in oratory. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> ... the <i>taiaha</i>, a kind of two-handed sword made of the hardest wood of the country; and the <i>tewhatewha,</i> a wooden battle-axe, having a sharp-pointed handle to enable it also to answer the purpose of a spear. <i>(1856,Traditions & Superstitions,244</i>)

>  <b>TREGEAR</b> Another weapon of authority or direction was the battle-axe (<i>tewha-tewha</i> or <i>paiaka</i>) made of bone or hard wood. <i>(1904,Maori Race, The,312</i>)

>  <b>BAUCKE</b> <i>(1928,Where the White Man Treads,57, 137</i>)

>  <b>REISCHEK</b> Others carried wooden lances or long, hatchet-like weapons called tewhatewha. <i>(1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,152,1933 ed.</i>)

>  The energy of the paddling - the rhythm of it! The time-giver stood on the thwarts, a feather-tufted <i>tewha tewha</i> in his extended hand; ... the time-giver sang his song ... <i>(1930,NZ Short Stories,30</i>) [NOTES: J.C.Anderson]

>  <b>BUCK</b> <i>(1944,Coming of the Maori, The,2/274</i>)

>  The Constabulary at work in the vicinity of the Gate Pah unearthed a perfect handsome tewhatewha of whalebone, solid, with blade eight inches long. <i>(Jun 10, 1876,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  A Tewhatewha or paiaka, a wooden P-shaped weapon, with hawk-feathers tied below the blade, looks innocent now under the glass, but it figured grimly only in a treacherous murder in the time of William IV., 1832. <i>(Feb 18, 1911,Evening Post,9</i>)

## that'll be the day
 
 <i>phr.</i> expressing doubt, disapproval, etc., of a statement or request; used ironically for something most unlikely to happen. [also that will be the day; (cf. 1867 Lady Barker Station Life (1874) 113 [a cockie speaks] `Ah but it'll be a far day first [before I'll believe that].) ca1935 at least e.g. `I thought you were at church.' `That'll be the day.' `That'll be the day when you see me there.']

>  "That will be der ruddy tag," said the bloke. <i>(Jan 10, 1944,NZEF Times,III/133 : 7</i>)

>  "That'll be the day," chorused half a dozen Kiwis. <i>(Dec 18, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/182 : 5</i>)

>  "THE DAY THE BOOKIES WEPT" .. That WILL be the Day! Under that'll be the day <i>(Feb 7, 1940,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> <i>That'll be the day!</i> used as a cant phrase expressing mild doubt... <i>(1941,NZ Slang,50</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>That'll be the day! </i>`Expressing mild doubt following some boast or claim,' B., 1941: New Zealand: C. 20. See also <i>day, that'll be the. </i> <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1199</i>)

>  <b>HARVEY</b> I asked some Wellington people if they'd like a shine, and all they said was, `You've got a bloody nerve,' or `That'll be the day,' or something mean like that. <i>(1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,35</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> <i>That'll be the day,</i> a way of expressing a strong disinclination to do something, was unknown to visiting Americans during the war, one of whom thought it expressed gay anticipation and answered `That'll be the day' when asked to visit a New Zealand family. The expression was worked to death and in its dying agonies produced some contortions as <i>That'll be the frosty Friday</i> etc. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,177</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>That'll be the day</i> c/p expressing doubt or incredulity; NZ since 1930s, widespread elsewhere; also, <i>that'll be the bloody day, boy! </i> <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112</i>)

>  <b>MARSH</b> He's a beaut. Wait till I get him. That'll be the day. <i>(1943,Colour Scheme,101</i>)

>  <b>MARSH</b> `If I've bungled', Alleyn muttered, `I've .. bungled in a big way.' .. Bailey astonished everyone by saying .. `That'll be the day.' `Don't talk Australian', Mr Fox chided. <i>(1951,Opening Night,248</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Onward. "That'll be the Day," we say. "The Day" is getting closer. <i>(1983,Down from Marble Mountain,239</i>)

>  "That'll be the day!" she snorted. <i>(Aug 14, 1947,NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,17</i>)

>  That will be the Day... Tokyo will get worse punishment that London ever got. "That will be the day." <i>(Sep 7, 1942,NZEF Times,II/62 : 8</i>)

## they're off, Mr Cutts
 
 <i>phr.</i>

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> In 1875 G.G.Stead (1841-1908), the famous race-horse owner, bought a half-share in Redwood's racing stud. Under the partnership agreement Stead managed the business side while the training was put in the hands of E. Cutts. The horses were raced in the name of one or other of the partners. This arrangement, which proved immensely successful, lasted into the 1890s and was terminated when Stead bought out Redwood's share of the stud. During his lifetime Henry Redwood was known as `the Father of the New Zealand Turf.' <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/58</i>)

>  <b>SCRYMGEOUR</b> One student [of Canterbury Agricultural College], ... the son of a sporting and well-known racing baronet of North Canterbury, would take Jim into the stables at `Cutts' to see the horses in training; ... <i>(1960,Memories of Maoriland,60</i>)

>  They're off, Mr Cutts!' At least, they will be about three o'clock today (Saturday), and in less than four minutes afterwards, you will all know whether you have lost your money or not. <i>(Nov 4, 1911,NZ Truth,332/6/4</i>)

>  <b>BENNETT</b> Horse-racing, another popular pastime (including trotting races, or <i>the trots</i>) provides two colloquialisms which need explanation. The exclamation `They're off, Mr Cutts!', announcing that any contest or affair has begun, contains the name of a one-time popular starter at the Auckland races. <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> Examples of slang and colloquial expressions of local origin are ... <i>they're off Mr Cutts,</i> for `the performance is about to start',... <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680</i>) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

>  <b>BAKER</b> ...they're off Mr Cutts!, meaning `things have started!' and or `now we're getting down to business!' <i>(1941,NZ Slang,50</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>They're off, Mr Cutts</i>. is a C. 20 New Zealand shape (B., 1941) cf:- [monkey] <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1200</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>they're off, Mr Cutts!</i> the race has begun; Partridge identifies as a variant of `they're off', said the monkey', usually indicating start of a horse race, hence as something that has come loose; often with addition: `when he looked into the lawnmower and carelessly lost his testicles.' This addition may explain Mr Cutts. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112</i>)

>  "They're off, Mr Cutts!" Heaven only knows where the expression originated, but elderly Ted Cutts, Clifford's trainer, who is the person mentioned, was at Trentham, with his white hair trailing in the breeze. <i>(Jan 25, 1908,NZ Truth,1</i>)

>  THEY'RE OFF, MR CUTTS!! What's that left? Kennaquhair? No, that's Kennaquhair out in front, with Poitrel! <i>(May 4, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,1</i>)

## this side
 
 <i>phr.</i> sc. of the Tasman; New Zealand (a response to THE OTHER SIDE, Australia)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Australian aborigine words which were new to this side. In 1851 a number of Australian `squatters' came over and took up runholding in Canterbury, but, generally speaking, their advent was some years later in Otago. ... They brought over a number of Australian aborigine words that were new to this side, and which were used a certain amount, usually in a joking manner as far as I know. I have heard some of them fairly frequently used by the `old hands,' sometimes oracularly and sometimes as a semi-humorous quotation. When I was a boy I heard sheep called `jumbucks,' an Australian aborigine term for them, but with the decease of ex-Australian stockmen the word has gone out of use now. Another term brought over from Australia was `maimai,' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a blackfellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt `miamia,' and which is called `gunyah' or `wurley,' etc., by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,10</i>)

## thrash
 
 <i>v.</i> to overwork (anything mechanical, espec. an engine or vehicle) excessively; to work or drive at an excessive pace hence, to overwork or overexploit soil, country, a trapping block, a fishery, etc.; to take more than a sustained yield espec. as a ppl aj <i>thrashed,</i> `overexploited; ruined, done in (mechanically)' [ca1938 Havelock That car's been pretty well thrashed after only three thousand miles if the rings are gone.]

>  <b>CRUMP</b> I found that deer don't hang about in the open once you start thrashing [sc. overshooting] a place, and it became necessary to go farther and farther along the range. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,24</i>)

>  <b>LAWSON</b> We raced her past the Brothers,/And thrashed her through the Straits,/And where the wild rip smothers ... <i>(1903,Red West Road,17</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to move cattle by use of stockwhip

>  [The cattle] were in two mobs ... We commenced thrashing them about 8 a.m. and by 7 p.m. had verilly thrashed them over some 20 miles. I never [125] thrashed cattle so much before. <i>(Mar 15, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,124,1950 ed.</i>)

>  Wilkinson & James thrashing. <i>(Jul 21, 1866,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

## throw
 
 <i>v.</i> of humans, to give birth to vicariously (here transf.) (cp. drop)

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> Bob? Didn't you hear? He threw twins pretty smartly to dodge the draft. <i>(1944,Troop Target,24</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  FAULT.- A fissure, accompanied by a displacement of the strata, same as a slide, heave, hitch, throw, and trouble. <i>(1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,54</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> When the round of holes was fired each was detonated in sequence from the front and all the broken rock was heaped up at the opposite end of the shaft, this being the `throw' of the holes. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,179</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> in main sense of cast

>  <b>MACNICOL</b> George had to be shown how to pick up a fleece and how to / throw it. <i>(1965,Skippers Road,93</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR</b> Bill hadn't learned to pick up and throw a fleece, and he felt the anger of a fleeco was directed at him for not getting stuck in when the shearer cried, `Wool away!' ... Fleecos hated this; it made the fleece difficult to throw. The aim was to stand by as the shearer made his last blow, gather the fleece into a compact armful, and throw it like a tablecloth on the wooltable, weather side up. <i>(1981,Sunrise,46</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to fell, cut through, or knock down [(cf. DROP, KNOCK DOWN)]

>  The pines should be thrown last because then they do not cover up the other stuff until it is dry. <i>(Nov 10, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/158</i>) [NOTES: H.A. Atkinson]

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> ... the trees are thrown with the x [sic] cut saw and American axe. <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/331</i>)

>  <b>WELCH</b> ... trees thrown with a cross-cut saw and American axe. <i>(1863,NZ Guide,22</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> They could fell a tree in real bushwhackers' style, and could judge best how to `throw' the tree too. <i>(1905,Bush Boys of NZ,138</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to put on; perform etc (See [wobbly; sickie; hollywood](../W#wobbly;-sickie;-hollywood))



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [land] to produce feed for stock.

>  This farm 'throws a lot of feed before Christmas,' he says. <i>(Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,84</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to throw an animal to the ground

>  <b>ROBERTS</b> At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, ... The yard was divided into three - ... but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring brands, and ... legroped and threw them ...[chk] <i>(Dec 18, 1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43]



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> of a crop, to reap [[see DROP (a tree) for quot]]

## throw open
 
 <i>v.</i> sc. a block of land, for settlement

>  <b>BELL</b> If I had a couple of hundred acres of good bush land, and a wife like that girl down there would make, I wouldn't call the Queen my aunt; and, by Jove! I mean to have a buck at some of those sections in the Whakatangi Block that'll be thrown open shortly, ... <i>(1899,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,84</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> The system of `free selection' enabled a would-be `cockatoo' to choose land in localities `thrown open' to selectors (under certain conditions regarding residence, improvement, and area) and to buy the freehold. <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,155</i>)

>  The circumstamces under which they occupied the land had been explained at a former meeting, and it was resolved to remain satisfied with what had been done until the natives could be induced to throw open the Upper Thames. <i>(Oct 19, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,4</i>)

>  All the pettifogging attempts that have been made to prevent land being thrown open sink into insignificance - collapse like a punctured balloon - when pierced and confronted by plain facts. <i>(Apr 29, 1874,Tuapeka Times,3</i>)

>  The Lands Department will throw open about 59,000 acres of first and second class land in the Bay of Plenty districts. <i>(Jan 31, 1903,West Coast Times,3</i>)

>  Altogether, such a course would throw open about five thousand acres for settlement. <i>(Jul 23, 1912,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN, that on Monday, June 6, 1842, the township of Wanganui and Country Sections in that district will be thrown open for selection at the Resident Surveyor's Office at Wanganui, at 11 A.M. precisely, and close at 4 P.M.; one half the choices will be made on the first day, and the remainder on the second or following day. <i>(May 4, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to offer or make free land for selection or balloting.

>  <b>WARD</b> We have thought and deemed it proper to throw open all the country ... <i>(1858,BLANK ENTRY,45</i>) [NOTES: in Reeves (1883) Canterbury Rhymes]

>  It is rumored - but we can't vouch for the accuracy of it - that as soon as road lines are cut through the bush country the land will be thrown open for free selection as was done in Canterbury ... <i>(Oct 6, 1880,Hawera Star,2</i>)

>  The surveyors are pushing on with the survey of the Waimarino block up the Wanganui River, part of which will shortly be open for application. <i>(Nov 1891,NZ Farmer,471</i>)

>  This is a sample of a large portion of the land shortly to be thrown open by the Crown ... <i>(Jun 1898,NZ Farmer,197</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> By Jove! I mean to have a buck at some of those sections in the Whakatangi Block that'll be thrown open shortly. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,84</i>)

>  In one case, where a section was thrown open by the Government to be ballotted, there were over two hundred applicants. <i>(Mar 1907,NZ Farmer,214</i>)

>  With the idea of giving information to those acquiring land, there will be published in this column full particulars of all Crown, public, and native lands thrown open for settlement. <i>(1908,Weekly News,47</i>)

>  It is interesting to watch the development of an estate such as Starborough or Flaxbourne, which has been purchased by the government and thrown open to settlers. <i>(May 1909,NZ Farmer,394</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> Following its destruction, through man's agency by fore and stock, a huge area of virgin soil was, to use a New Zealand political term, 'thrown open' to selection. <i>(1921,Tutira,236</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> The system of 'free selection' enabled a would-be 'cockatoo' to choose land in localities 'thrown open' to selectors (under certain conditions regarding residence, improvement and area) and to buy the freehold. <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,115</i>)

## thunderplump
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  DELUGED [heading] I am beginning to think that I must be the only ignoramus in Dunedin who has never heard of a thunderplump. Everyone else has known the word since childhood and, as a Buccleugh Street reader neatly put it, I was fairly deluged with thunderplumps yesterday. Other readers wanted to explain that `plumps' were to be found in many dictionaries, but I was aware of that anyway. Most of the people who knew of thunderplump claimed a Scottish origin for it, but it still took me quite a time to locate it in my range of dictionaries. Finally I ran it to earth in a seven-volume Century, published back in 1891, which gave it as `A short violent downpour of rain in connection with a thunder-storm (Rare),' and produced a 19th century quotation. Perhaps we didn't hear it much in Invercargill in my younger days because thunderplumps are pretty uncommon there; but a colleague who came from Winton certainly knew of it; and it was even noised abroad by the Canterbury English. ... <i>(Nov 18, 1977,Otago Daily Times</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

## ti mi
 
 <i>n.</i> ?tainui <i>Pomaderris apetala</i>

>  <b>PAULIN</b> Among the trees Mr. Traill pointed out [on Stewart Island], was what he called a `Ti Mi' tree, and which he said was only found growing in one place in New Zealand, that being Mokai, on the west coast of the North Island. He stated that the Maori tradition about it was this - that the first Maoris who visited New Zealand came in a large canoe built of `Ti Mi' wood, and they landed at Mokaia, where there is a good harbour. canoe got broken up, and some of the planks took root and grew.' Paulin WWC, pp. 33-4. [Andersen notes:] The canoe referred to was the `Tainui', and the tree is said to be the karaka or kopi. White Ancient History Maori (1890), vol. 4, p. 38. ## ti-palm
 
 <i>n.</i> ti, cabbage tree <i>Cordyline australis</i> [incl tipalm, also ti palm] (See [also ti](../A#also-ti),[ti-ti palm](../T#ti-ti-palm))

>  <b>POLACK</b> The provisions consisted of about three thousand baskets of potatoes, kumeras, ... steamed kernels of the karaka [a's-acute] maori, tarro [a-acute], ...: the baked roots of the Ti palm, &c. graced the festal scene. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/229</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> A long lane was formed on an extensive level plain, fifty feet in width, by two high walls, formed by perhaps upwards of ten thousand baskets of potatoes, kumeras, Indian corn (<i>Holcus indicus</i>), tarro (<i>arum</i>), water melons, turnips preserved, (<i>kou</i>) steamed kernels of the native fruit, (<i>karaka</i>[as-acute]) baked roots of the <i>ti</i> palm tree, (<i>korou</i>) a quantity of dried cod, eels and other fish, also of shell-fish, bundles of fern-root, onions, peaches, grapes, &c. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/91</i>)

>  <b>SELWYN</b> Walked over a beautiful grass plain [south Canterbury] ... after twelve miles covered with the Ti palm; ... <i>(Jan 18, 1844,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 18 Selwyn Journal in 1851 NZ Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 14]

>  Country undeviating grass and ti-palm. <i>(Mar 4, 1849,Torlesse Papers,64,1958 ed.</i>)

>  The appearance of Ti palms on the Canterbury plains is very remarkable. They rise amidst the short rich grass with their thick stalks and graceful crest; often when one looks up suddenly from the ground, startling with their likeness to men. One of our wags remarked of these plants, that they looked `like men as trees walking'. A less observant youth having lost his way a few nights ago, in the neighbourhood of the capital, was cheered in the loneliness of the prairie, by the appearance of a man approaching. He took off his hat, (not having yet forgotten the courteous address of the old country,) and accosted the stranger, `I beg your pardon, sir, but can you tell me which is the way to Christchurch.' It was a Ti palm. <i>(Apr 12, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5</i>)

>  <i>(Jan 1856,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal</i>) [NOTES: Tancred Notes on the Natural History of ... Canterbury (And)]

It has not the least resemblance to a cabbage. <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iii/33-34</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> Ti-ti palms are dotted here and there. <i>(1866,Station Days in Maoriland,52,1874 ed.</i>)

## ti-tree
 
 <i>n.</i> ti, cabbage tree [one cit only]

## tick tack
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> One common prank was Knick Knock. In this game, children knocked on someone's door, then ran away, but it could be played more elaborately: In Tick Tack we stuck a pin into the middle sash of a window; a button was suspended from this on a piece of cotton. Then a long length of cotton was attached to the smaller piece and led away to the gate. The cotton was pulled every now and then and the button tapped against the window. It was nighttime, and folks would pull up the blind and peer out. Some more adventurous spirits would come out and investigate and would maybe get entangled with the cotton. Then the culprit would run away to some other house. (1900; Moeraki) <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,90</i>)



## tick tick
 
 <i>exclam.</i>

>  <b>WATT</b> A warning like the English schoolboys' `cave!'. From J. M. Barrie's <i>Peter Pan</i> where Hook was always warned of the approach of the crocodile because of the ticks of the alarm clock it had swallowed. If a master approaches, the boys warn the rest with `tick tick!'. Also used in the expression `to go tick' - that is, to go on watch for masters and prefects while the rest get into mischief. <i>(1951,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1951 Dilworth School (McWatt letter)]

## ticket boy

## tie-down
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a deadman anchor [used to secure fenceposts.]

>  <b>MOWAT</b> Joe & I went round the fence round Middle Hills & put in a few tie-downs. <i>(Oct 9, 1908,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> He dug holes for posts and learned how stays and 'tie-downs' were used. <i>(1954,On the Hill,22</i>)

>  <b>DU FAUR</b> The use of chains for tie-downs, where footed posts are normally used, has become popular and effective. <i>(1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,193</i>)

>  Then it was a matter of setting to to make the Taranaki gates as we discussed. Have completed three gates and dug in nine tie-downs but still more will be needed. <i>(Jun 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,32</i>)

>  Clearing sale .. Insul timber posts and tie-downs, Waratah standards.. <i>(Nov 10, 1993,Napier Daily Telegraph,21</i>)

>  Tie-downs: (See dead man). Wire that ties the dead man to the post. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,30</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> By letting go a tie-down just along the fence he manages to get the fence wires done up in the same twists they were in before. He loses a bit of tension on the tie-down but no one's going to notice that. <i>(1989,Bullock Creek,92</i>)



## tie-up
 
 <i>n.</i> [from taiepa, see]

>  A favourite dodge of the Maoris was to put a "tie-up" or Maori fence across the roads being formed. <i>(Nov 9, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,39</i>)

## tier
 
 <i>n.</i> ? a coating of clay or earth on a ? sod or wattle and daub house; ? or tie-beam

>  Fine weather, Chapman shepherding Wedders, put tier on house &c [24] no tier got on house clay wet [Mar 31] put last tier and wall plates on house. [Apr 2] clayed walls of house put on tie beams [3] finished claying & put on ridge pole & rafters of house. [Apr 4] nailed wattles on roof [Apr 5] commenced thatching house. [Apr 12] put in clay in eaves and put tier on gable and chimney, [14] put tier on gable and chimney & tier of small stove, <i>(Mar 19, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary</i>) [NOTES: [Hocken TS]]



## tier-pole
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a rack of parallel bars upon which curing-sticks rest in the curing of tobacco.

>  They [curing-sticks] usually carry from eight to ten plants, and are hung in the shed by resting the ends of the sticks on tier-poles. These are strong squared timber, 2in by 4in., lying horizontally, and held in position by bolting them to uprights .. If the distance between curing-sticks on the tier-poles is reckoned at 8 in., it is now possible to work out the accommodation required for curing the crop. <i>(Nov 21, 1927,NZ Journal of Agriculture,340</i>)

>  The stick is placed on tier poles, which run like parallel bars in the curing-shed. <i>(Jan 21, 1929,NZ Journal of Agriculture,59</i>)

## tiger country
 
 <i>n.</i> [figurative, far off the local area, esp in sport]

>  <b>DAVIES</b> Come down to Wellington if you feel that your batteries need to be recharged. I think it's going to be tiger country up there for a permanent union official, but we trust you to do your best. <i>(1984,Bread and Roses,177</i>)

>  Duncan's was the longer ball, but it kicked off the fairway into the "tiger country" to the left. <i>(Nov 11, 1932,Evening Post,11</i>)

>  Goss, after a pulled drive, hooked his second at "Alma" away into the tiger country. <i>(Oct 6, 1923,NZ Truth,9</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) wild, isolated and steep country [usually scrub-covered and difficult to access and traverse.]

>  At the moment the Department [of Lands] is confined to buying areas that can be divided into multiple units. This restricts them to the real 'tiger' country. <i>(Dec 10, 1964,NZ Dairy Exporter,13</i>)

>  Much of the land is 'tiger' country, in gullies and gulches, wide riverbeds and faces leading sharply to broken tops. <i>(May 11, 1968,Napier Daily Telegraph,5</i>)

>  It's tiger country all right. David has 15,380 acres in a longish block without even a track to his far boundary. <i>(Jul 8, 1971,NZ Farmer,32</i>)

>  The Thomas family had farmed happily and well enough on their 760 ha. home block of medium to tiger country for the first 20 years or so. <i>(May 13, 1982,NZ Farmer,14</i>)

>  <b>HOLDEN</b> This was the type of steep, grey-walled stuff that on the West Coast they refer to with some pride as 'tiger country.' <i>(1991,Fall Muster,22</i>)

>  Rightly or wrongly, some would call the 520 ha Okoki Valley property farmed by Graeme and Marise Northcott 'Tiger Country.' [big tiger country ] <i>(Nov 18, 1999,NZ Farmer,19</i>)

>  <b>LETHBRIDGE</b> It had been pretty hard `tiger' country in the first place, but when the land had been cleared ... the subsequent pasture was good enough ... to run a dairy herd. <i>(1971,Sunrise on the Hills,126</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> This road . . . winds its way through the harsh `tiger' country which typifies much of that [Marlborough Sounds] locality. <i>(1973,Big Country,32,1977 ed.</i>)

>  Surveyors and geologists use the term `tiger country' ...for the areas of low manuka scrub mixed with second growth native trees in the Rotorua-Taupo district (replacing forest destroyed by erruptions). Geologists say it is country only a tiger could get through, but I have suggested it may derive from the Siberian <i>`taiga'. </i> <i>(1980,NZ Geochemical Group Newsletter,No. 57/12</i>)

>  They come from a mostly fatherless family settling on the Pori Hill's legendary `tiger country', <i>(May 9, 1987,Dominion,11</i>)

## tight

 <i>adj.</i> of country, difficult to work [1898 [see index and discards]]



 
 <i>adj.</i> close

## tight as...
 
 <i>phr.</i> very mean (espec. with money), often further elaborated by adding `and that's watertight'; very drunk; (in various expressions of comparison with TIGHT in the senses: (1) close-fisted (P: mostly US: 1828; so WF); and (2) drunk (where NZ English would perhaps prefer FULL AS)) [ca1948 Wellington (Douglas Gray) cf. At present Canterbury residents refer to<i> R. retropinna</i> as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. ## timber-jack
 
 <i>n.</i> [aka timber jack]

>  On country too steep for bullocks the bushmen themselves moved the logs with tools called 'timber jacks' that they cranked by hand. <i>(Apr 2003,NZ Memories,No. 41/50</i>)

>  <b>BAINES</b> The principal tools required [by the kauri bushman] were Yankee axes, cross-cut saws, and timber (not screw) jacks. <i>Ibid.</i> 173 (Northland) Timer jacks [are] better than scew -jacks ... The timber-jacks consist of a toothed spear, two pinions, a cogged wheel, all of wrought iron, and properly arranged in a strong piece of wood. A double handle puts in motion the gear, and the spear can be ground out about two feet with power, one man being able to lift at the handle a ton easily. <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,171</i>)

>  Flotation is the method most commonly used in the kauri districts ... After the trunks are cut into lengths a `rolling-road' is formed to the nearest creek. All the scrub is closely cut down for a width of from twenty-five to thirty feet ... to obtain an approximately even surface, inclined towards the creek. The logs are forced along this road by timber-jacks, which the bushmen use with remarkable skill, and are impelled with a rapidity which is simply astonishing to persons unused to the process. If the creek contains plenty of water the logs float to the nearest booms without further trouble ... <i>(1894,NZ Official Yearbook,131</i>) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

>  <b>KIRK</b> The [kauri] logs are propelled along these roads by `timber-jacks' until they reach the water. <i>(1889,Forest Flora,150</i>)

>  <b>BARL;OW</b> ... timber jack. <i>(1889,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,112</i>)

>  <b>BODELL</b> This man had taken my 2 timber Jacks and cooking Utensils from the Mill ... <i>(1890,Soldier's View of Empire, A,211,1982 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> TIMBER JACK: See Screwjack. <i>(1961,Friends in Chains,189</i>) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 189]

>  <b>MALFROY</b> [caption] TIMBER-JACK MADE IN NEW ZEALAND ... This is a ... well-tried-out jack which is extensively used in logging operations from North Cape to the Bluff <i>(1923,Small Sawmills,21</i>)

>  <b>MOORE</b> The bushmen that did this work were a tough capable lot - a race apart - whom no difficulty could deter, and who performed amazing feats with a few quite primitive tools. These were axes, maul, and wedges, crosscut saws, mattocks for earth work, pinching bars or crowbars, and the versatile New Zealand-made timber jack. These jacks weighed about 80 pounds and by geared cogs multiplied the man power applied to the revolving handles so that the `spear' with its two chisel points, when applied to a log, could exert a lifting pressure of 5 tons. <i>(1969,From Forest to Farm,38</i>)

>  We may also mention that Mr. Masefield has on hand a quantity of saw-mill machinery, timber-jacks, &c. <i>(Mar 24, 1869,Daily Southern Cross,4</i>)

>  Re the timber-jack: To the best of my knowledge this wonderful instrument of the bushman is solely a New Zealand tool made in the sixties of the last century by that well-known firm of engineers, A. and G. Price, Ltd., of Thames, and later still by Messrs. Judd Bros., also of Thames, for the use of the sawmillers in the Coromandel and North Auckland kauri forests. <i>(Aug 14, 1941,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  Receiving no reply to their knocks, they forced open four doors with a timber-jack before gaining entrance to the lower part of the building. <i>(Sep 20, 1933,Evening Post,11</i>)

>  Everything in the shape of staging planks, chains and ropes, crowbars, timber jacks, and other gear is thrown overboard and there is considerable delay and expense in replacing these work tools. <i>(Mar 25, 1914,Grey River Argus,5</i>)

>  <b>HAWKE & SCOTT</b> First timber jacks were used [sc. for stumping] and later a Trewella stumping machine which had a thirteen ton pull on it <i>(1985,Early Farm Machinery in NZ,129</i>)

>  Two ploughs, 2 drays, 1 spring dray .. 4 tons chaff, road scoop, timber jack .. also household furniture of every description too numerous to particularise. <i>(May 26, 1908,Grey River Argus,3</i>)

>  Everything in the shape of staging planks, chains and ropes, crowbars, timber jacks, and other gear is thrown overboard and there is considerable delay and expense in replacing these work tools. <i>(Mar 25, 1914,Grey River Argus,5</i>)

## tin mill
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a small tractor-led metal threshing mill [widely used on individual farms and requiring seven or eight men to operate.]

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> tin mill: see combine. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,85</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> His main source of income, the cocksfoot seed, is harvested in the old way, in sheaves, with a binder and an old tin mill. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,1</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> The direct descendant of the tin mill is the combine harvester, or header, of today, the only real difference between the two being that the mill lacks an engine, cutter bar and self-motivation. Jim's got four tin mills but uses only two, one on each farm. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,10</i>)

>  <b>OGILVIE</b> Next to the header harvester, the `tin' mill did the mill [sc. threshing] men most disservice. This smaller style of mill came in with the tractor by which it was drawn and driven. The `tin' mill only needed seven or eight men to operate it, and its output was no more than half that of the `big' mill. But within a short time these small mills became so popular that many farmers bought their own and could thresh their grain exactly when it suited them and their crops. The `tin' mill and the `Sunshine' header thus put an effective end to the era of the mill men [in South Canterbury]. <i>(1971,Moonshine County,158</i>)

>  <b>NEAVE</b> Then the tin mill and tractor came in, ... and [threshing] work was reduced to a few days only. <i>(1980,Land of Munros, The,90</i>)

>  The tin mill is smaller, slower but more portable [sc. than the threshing mill]. <i>(1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(7) : 10</i>)

## tin-kettler
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <i>A Tin-kettling Episode</i>: The detestable practice of tin-kettling a newly-married couple [with kerosine tins] doesn't seem to die out like other barbarities in this country; it is a relic of by-gone days. ... The origin of the custom has never been authoritatively determined and whether it is an English or purely Colonial custom ... doesn't appear to be known. However, the tin-kettlers expect the happy bridegroom to stop the din by handing them cakes and ale. ... It is only the idiotic low-class class of people who would go banging tin-cans opposite a man's house after dark ... . <i>(Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/8/3</i>)

Stone folder (ATB MS)]

Stone folder (ATB MS)]

## tin-kettling
 
 <i>n.</i> (formerly) a custom whereby a newly-wed couple are welcomed to their marriage home by noisy banging of kerosene (etc.) tins until they provide the tin-kettlers with refreshments. [also called tin-canning]

>  This was called "tin-canning" or "tin-kettling," and newly married couples were those who suffered. <i>(Mar 25, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,16</i>)

The origin of the custom has never been authoritatively determined and whether it is an English or purely Colonial custom ... doesn't appear to be known. However, the tin-kettlers expect the happy bridegroom to stop the din by handing them cakes and ale. ... It is only the idiotic low-class class of people who would go banging tin-cans opposite a man's house after dark ... <i>(Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/8/3</i>)

>  Napuka ( <i> Hebe speciosa </i> ), also known as the titirangi shows off its bottle-brush flowers all year round. <i>(Dec 2006,Growing Today,30</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Titirangi (Middle Island), <i>Lyall</i>. Veronica speciosa. <i>(1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768 ed.</i>)

>  <i>titirangi</i>, a plant (Veronica speciosa), one of a very numerous family. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]



## titiwai
 
 <i>n.</i> the glow-worm, <i>Archnocampa luminosa</i>

>  The titiwai (stars in wet places) of Waitomo, which means water entering a shaft, have been celebrated since 1887, when they were first explored by local Maori chief Tane Tinorau. The insects feed ravenously as larvae, then briefly emerge as adult fungus gnats to mate, lay eggs and die within three days. <i>(Dec 9, 2003,BLANK ENTRY,A11</i>)



## title
 
 <i>n.</i> an abbreviation of <i>certificate of title</i>, a copy of the entry in the land titles register recording the identity and ownership of a piece of land and any legal encumbrances on it. [Jim Cameron writes : The English equivalent in relation to registered land there is <i>land certificate</i>. The term <i>title deeds</i> is sledom used in NZ. The attached clippings illustrate an aspect of its general use e.g. <i>on separate titles, titles pending</i>.]

>  Some New Zealand land law terms are uncommon or unknown in England. (Conversely the term title deeds is not much used here either by lawyers or laymen. Instead we talk of the title or certificate of title, in the concrete sense of a document which is a copy of the registry entry in the Land Transfer Office. <i>(Jan 1999,NZWords,1</i>)



## title deeds
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The land transfer system contrasted with the older deeds system, introduced in 1841 as a reformed version of traditional English real property law whereby rights to ownership depended on the existence and validity of a chain of documents. The term title deeds derives from this. <i>(Jan 1999,NZWords,2</i>)



## title unit
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The plan was to divide it into two title units and sell it. <i>(Sep 12, 2000,Evening Post,13</i>)

## tito
 
 <i>n.</i> a fib, a lie. [ORIGIN: Maori, ca1900 King Country (J. Morison) ca1935 Havelock in pron. [|ti:tou]]

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> [The natives] were sure we were telling them tito, `lies'. <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,2/43</i>)

>  <b>POWER</b> It is a pity [the Maories] do not extend the same condemnation to lying, which is an almost universal failing, and is considered no disgrace whatsoever ... [146] The consequence is, that the natives are generally distrustful and incredulous; and `toe' and `teto', lie and liar, are the words most frequently heard in their conversation, and which they apply to one another and to white men of all ranks without the least hesitation or compunction. <i>(Dec 13, 1847,Sketches in NZ,145</i>)

>  <b>DOMETT</b> `A <i>tito</i> this - a fib, I know; <i>(1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/190</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [ca1935 Havelock]

>  <b>GUTHRIE</b> ... most natives thought nothing of it, looking upon it as a joke if, finding them out in one, you called them <i>`tito'</i> or liar. <i>(1930,NZ Memories,82</i>)



## titoki

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> The hair is often greased with ... an oil pressed from the seeds of the titoki (Aledron [sic] excelsum, belonging to the Sapindaceae). <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,2/54</i>)

>  <i>(Jul 29, 1844,Report of Select Committee on NZ</i>) [NOTES: 1844 July 29 House of Commons Report of Select Committee on NZ (And)]

## tits on toast

## tizzie

## toby
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Kokopu had been found in stormwater drains, toby holes, and hidden under leaves on moist ground. <i>(May 7, 2001,Evening Post,18</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a raddle stick

>  <b>PROF. DARCY WALKER</b> He did not hear it till c1955 when he came to Wellington cf Macquarie: <i>toby</i> = stick used by owner to raddle badly-shorn sheep with. <i>(Nov 8, 1983,Personal Communication</i>)

>  <i>raddled:</i> This word means `robbed' in the sense of being deprived of one's proper payment. It is an extension of `raddling', carried out by unscrupulous farmers before the Shearers' Union looked after shearers' interests. Any sheep considered unsatisfactorily shorn was marked with red or blue raddle and such a sheep would not be counted in the shearer's tally. The raddle stick was also called a `Toby'. This must not be confused with [27] marking a sheep for other purposes, such as identification of certain sheep for easy selection later. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3.26</i>) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]



 
 <i>n.</i> A stop-cock or valve in a water- or gas-main, gen. in a roadway at which the supply may be turned off, also applied to the covering, lid or box protecting it [Frequently toby box or toby-box; ca1954 Upper Hutt (Val Kiddie)(This was the first time I had heard the word used: I had always called it the `stopcock'. HWO) ; 1955 occas. seen (but not recorded) in the Evening Post --->ca1960 Karori, Wellington]

>  <b>STANDARDS INSTITUTE</b> <i>(1956,Glossary of Building Terminology</i>)

>  Where necessary, street-front tobies [water stopcocks] would be turned off and sealed to prevent firms turning the water back on. <i>(Apr 12, 1999,Dominion,7</i>)

>  Wellington City Council worker Chris Cashen was inspecting a flooded toby in Miramar a few days ago when he saw objects wriggling in the water. <i>(Jan 29, 2001,Evening Post,16</i>)

>  I must correct you as to the origin of 'toby'. It's not Irish for road. It is Gaelic for 'spring'. My ancestors built the navigation canals in the UK. That's why they were called 'navvies' and they took the word toby with them. I'm fluent in the Gaelic, so trust me! <i>(Feb 14, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48</i>)

>  I also recommend that all the toby-boxes should be cast in a small block of concrete, as I find that a good many of them get shifted from their positions. <i>(May 2, 1901,Hawera & Normanby Star,4</i>)

>  She objected to the toby box on the bounday [sic], but he could not touch it. <i>(Jun 25, 1915,Poverty Bay Herald,5</i>)

>  All he did afterwards was to fix a new ball tap, do some minor repairs, and supply a toby-box of the value of 4s 6d. <i>(May 2, 1930,Evening Post,15</i>)

>  Toby - surface box generally set flush with paving or other surface to cover the stop-cock or control valve of a water or gas supply. <i>(1979,NZ Standards Council Glossary Building Term.,119</i>)

>  <i>Toby</i> - Surface box generally set flush with paving or other surface to cover the stop-cock or control valve of a water or gas supply. <i>(1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,119</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>toby</i>: (A) the MASTER WATER VALVE for a building ordinarily located under a metal cover in the sidewalk outside. Who was Toby anyway? `Turn off <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,104</i>)

>  A temporary worker had been engaged to detect unauthorised connections to council tobies (mains taps), and he had found the connections were mostly a normal hose connection to the toby. <i>(Apr 28, 1982,Evening Post,15</i>)

>  Large quantities of water have leaked from a toby in St Francis Grove, Lower Hutt, in the past few days, and the Lower Hutt City Council has done nothing to stop it, an angry woman resident says. <i>(Apr 18, 1985,Evening Post,32</i>) [NOTES: ? here a fire-hydrant valve?]

>  <i>toby n. </i>water stopcock on section boundary <i>(1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,504</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

>  <b>MARSHALL</b> I'll change the washer on that tap ... Go out and turn off the toby, will you dear. <i>(1985,Nest of Cuckoos,107</i>)

>  <b>JAMES M DERMODY, WARKWORTH</b> My parents, and I as a four-year-old, came out from Ireland in 1921. My father became involved in a new water-supply scheme for Blenheim. In the later 1920s the `toby-box' was an item of daily reference: my father had a small supply in his shed at home. They were a cast-iron cylinder of about four inches diameter and not much greater length. <i>(Nov 6, 1989,Personal Communication</i>)

>  What is the origin of the "toby". the tap that turns off water at the street frontage of a house?... I am prepared to wager that it is derived from "toby", which was the gypsy-tinker slang term for "street. There is an early link between tinkers and plumbers, both being experts with the soldering-iron, and I think the plumbers took over "toby" from the tinkers. Consequently, when they turned water off "at the toby" they were turning it off at the street. <i>(Jun 11, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56</i>) [NOTES: Ian Gordon]

## toe-biter
 
 <i>n.</i> Dobson fly larva, <i>Archichauliodes</i> sp, black creeper [aka toebiter]

>  insect larva Order 4 (alder-flies) is represented in New Zealand by only a single species <i>Archicauliodes dubitatus</i>, an insect of large size, whose fat, succulent larva is found under rocks in streams, and forms excellent food for trout. This larva is called the `black creper,' or sometimes the `toe-biter'. <i>(Jan 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,3/273</i>) [NOTES: (Tillyard)]

>  <b>NATUSCH</b> The Dobson fly ... is a speckled orange-winged insect which flits weakly over streams at dusk. The larva (known as the black creeper or toe-biter). . . hides under stones in the creek bed by day, coming out for a night's career with its powerful jaws ready to seize and devour whatever comes its way; <i>(1967,Animals of NZ, The,151</i>)

>  She made a sudden dip and scooped up a creature she identified as the nymph of a dobsonfly. "It's known as the 'toe-biter,'" she said, "on account of its large jaws and habit of nipping bare feet." <i>(Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 50/51</i>)

>  It is perfectly true that the big bags early in the season are obtained principally by the aid of the "toe-biter," which "hangs out" under stones near the water's edge; but matters adjust themselves later, for the "toe-biters" develop into a fly or something, and they are no longer found in any number. <i>(Nov 2, 1901,Nelson Evening Mail,2</i>)

## toe-ragger
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Toe-ragger, n.</i> In the bush a term of abuse; though curiously in one or two parts of New South Wales the word `toey,' which is derived from it, is a term of praise, a `swell.' The word has been explained as of convict origin, that the rags were used to soothe the galling of fetters; but the explanation is not satisfactory, for the part galled by the irons would not be the toe, but the ankle. A writer in `Truth' has cleared up the word (see quotation). It is of Maori origin. Away from Maoriland "toe-rigger' had no meaning, and a false meaning and origin were given by the change of vowel. <i>(1898,Austral English,472</i>)

>  `The bushie's favorite term of opprobrium `a toe-ragger' is also probably from the Maori. Amongst whom the nastiest term of contempt was that of <i>tau rika rika</i>, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers, and to-day the word in the form of toe-ragger has spread through-out the whole of the South Seas.' <i>(Jan 12, 1896,Truth (Sydney)</i>)

>  <i>toe-ragger n.</i> a term of abuse. [corrupt. fr. Maori tau rika rika, a slave] <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Toe-ragger, rigger</i>. A term of opprobrium: Australia and New Zealand resp., as in <i>Truth</i> (the Sydney one), Jan. 12, 1896, `"A toe-ragger' is Maori... The nastiest term of contempt was <i>tua rika rika,</i> or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other <i>toe-riggers</i>, and to-day the word in the form <i>toe-ragger</i> has spead throughout the whole of the South Seas.' Morris. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,893</i>)

>  <b>McNAB</b> Slang words of Maori origin were once common, but most of them are dead and dying [including] "toe-ragger,' a curse (taurekareka); ... <i>(Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> Another old whaling term - this time a pejorative - is toe-rigger, which is the original of the still-current slang expression in Australia, <i>toe-ragger.</i> Here is what the Sydney Truth, January 12, 1896 had to say on the subject: "The bushie's favourite term of opprobrium, a toe-ragger, is...probably from the Maori, amongst whom the nastiest term of contempt was that of tau rika rika, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers and to-day the word in the form of toe-ragger has spread throughout the whole of the South Seas.' Morris also declares: `It is of Maori origin. Away from Maoriland toe-rigger had no meaning, and a false meaning and origin were given by the change of vowel.' <i>(1941,NZ Slang,14</i>)

>  <i>toe-ragger n.</i> term of contempt for a person down and out [from tramps who tied rags round their feet to prevent blistering]. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> <i>The toeragger was not much wealthier [as a swagger] than the battler. His name is from the rags he wore in lieu of socks. </i> <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,144</i>)

>  <i>toe-ragger n</i>. whalers' slang for a person to be despised. Also<i> toe-rigger</i> [From Maori <i>taurekareka</i>, slave]. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20</i>)

## toheroa stakes
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>THOMAS</b> But my friends in the far north tell tales of parties going to the beach to fish, and spending their time engrossed in a game known as the Toheroa Stakes. The game is based on the shellfish's remarkable ability to bury itself and disappear in the solid sand of the wet beach. ... The game is, or was, played by drawing a circle on the beach. Each player selects a toheroa. The bets are made. On the word go each toheroa is placed on its side within the circle. The first to disappear is the winner. <i>(1970,Way Up North,100</i>)

## tohungaism
 
 <i>n.</i> (historical, derogatory) sorcery or faith healing as formerly practised by (or alleged against) tohunga. [also as tohunga-ism; apparently a cause for concern among Pakeha c.1900, the word being frequently used in newspapers, etc.; a Tohunga Suppression Act was passed in 1908.]

>  I have met with scares which.. brought home to me.. that it be a criminal offence, punishable with hard-labour imprisonment, to practice tohungaism, boast of a tohungaistic reputation, apply to a tohunga for illegal operations, and learning the incantations, for the latter is the tap root of the upas tree. <i>(Feb 11, 1905,NZ Herald,Suppl. 1</i>)

>  The Tohunga Suppression Act of 1908 is now to be repealed although some Maoris say that tohungaism still exists. <i>(Nov 1, 1962,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: ca1962 Nov 1 NZBS News (9.00 a.m.)]

>  Tohungaism still flourishes among Maoris in Taranaki, according to evidence given at an inquest into the death of a Maori child, Marlene Davis, aged 17 months, at Hawera, states a New Plymouth correspondent. <i>(Jul 24, 1942,Evening Post,4</i>)

>  Tohungaism is not a lawful means of subsistence. <i>(Oct 1, 1904,NZ Observer,3</i>)

>  <b>Michael King</b> Although emphatically Maori in his use of language and metaphor, [Ratana] rejected many traditional practices and values such as tribalism, tangihanga, tapu, tohunga-ism and carving. <i>(2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,291</i>)

>  ... convert [Maoris] ... from heathenism and tohungaism. <i>(Dec 9, 1905,NZ Truth,25/5/6</i>)

>  <b>BAUCKE</b> In my recent outback explorations I have met with scenes which horrified ... and brought home to me ... the imperative necessity ... that it be a criminal offence, punishable with hard labour imprisonment, to practise tohungaism, boast of tohungaistic reputation, apply to a tohunga for illegal operations, and learning the incantations, ... <i>(1905,Where the White Man Treads,262</i>)

 <i>n.</i> South Island brown kiwi or the Stewart Island kiwi [Difference is unclear between these two headwords except that this one is more general and used before the specific naming of the newly defined species of the other headword. Also tokoweka.]

>  Indeed, it is now recognised that a number of related but genetically divergent varieties are clustered in the south-western corner of the country - the Stewart Island tokoeka, the Southern Fiordland tokoeka (found from Wilmot's Pass south), the Northern Fiordland tokoeka and the Haast tokoeka. <i>(Mar 2005,NZ Geographic,No. 72, p. 11</i>)

## Tommy
 
 <i>n.</i> ?collocation ENGLISH TOMMY, cf. (ENGLISH) JOHNNY

>  <b>MANSFIELD</b> ... all the men he phoned were fixd [sic] up except this young chap, just out from England who was staying at the Club. ... He seemed a decent sort of chap - quiet - a bit stand offish like most of these English `Tommies'. [This passage is crossed out.] [fn 164] `English Tommies": like the phrase `English Johnny' which Mansfield used in her story <i>Millie</i> in 1912, this is presumably a contemporary New Zealand expression for a recent immigrant. <i>(1916,Aloe, The,159,(1982 O'Sullivan) ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a bookmaker

>  In the strict letter of the law the bookmaker can refuse to change a wager as it takes two to make a bet and two to cry it off, but I do not remember a similar case where a `Tommy' refused to accommodate a client. <i>(Mar 30, 1907,NZ Truth,93/2/4</i>)

>  They were punched [?punted check] in through the front door of their old urinal - which is their present office - by that delightful organisation of talkative tommies known as the Burgesses' Association. <i>(Sep 7, 1907,NZ Truth,116/5/7</i>)

>  Wonder how bookmakers came to be known as `Tommies"? `Tommy [sic] is short for Tommy Rook, and probably it was owing to `rook' sounding something like "book' that caused some wag to term him as such. A rook would apply to some bookmakers, but where does the `Tommy' come in? The bookmakers were never named Tommies after soldiers, who are so dubbed, for when the latter lie on the field they've generally been shot at, whereas the bookie when he lays on the field, he's not been shot at, and, moreover, he never lays himself open to be shot at, either by marksmen or punters. Tommy is certainly a misnomer, and it should have been applied to a backer, who is ever the target for the unerring aim of the Bar Von. <i>(May 6, 1911,NZ Truth,306/2/4</i>)

>  <b>TUCKER</b> By the same token some of the bookmakers that I have known have been fearless fielders. There is a fascinating story of one of New Zealand's `tommies' who went through a very bad patch. <i>(1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,167</i>)

>  The Tommies got `rats' over the Napier Park meeting. The Hutt trained Moata's successes depleting the ring of a lot of money. <i>(May 23, 1907,NZ Truth,92/2/3</i>)

## tomo
 
 <i>n.</i> a cave or hole; a chute-like hole made by water in especially volcanic material. [Maori ?]; a water-worn hole; a sink-hole in limestone country f. ?Maori <i>tomoau</i>, abyss (Williams 435), or the noun f.

>  The drainage of this limestone dip-slope area is mostly underground by means of sink-holes or `tomos,' which are so common as to give the name `Tomo Country' to the district. <i>(1946,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.41 (NS) 20</i>) [NOTES: (Marwick, `The Geology of the Te Kuiti Subdivision') see also p. 37]

>  Te Kuiti, April 14 (P.A.) - A slip into a tomo (A water-worn hole) over 100 feet deep resulted in the death yesterday of ... of Oparue, Te Kuiti. ... A search resulted in the finding today of his rifle on the tomo edge ... <i>(Apr 14, 1952,Evening Post</i>) [NOTES: Apr 14 (?15 or 20th?)]

>  <i>(1952,Arena,31/3</i>)

>  <i>(1953,Short Stories (various authors),188</i>) [NOTES: 1953 Middleton in 1966 Short Stories 188]

>  <b>MASON</b> tomos with [Limestone hole] in brackets as explanation. Some way further north many tomos noted <i>(1954,Personal Communication,2</i>)

>  <b>MIDDLETON</b> `Coming to look for tomos?' he used to sing out ... <i>(1959,Stone, The,32</i>) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

>  <i>(1959,Tararua,xiii/47</i>)

>  <b>PARK</b> <i>(1961,Hole in the Hill,76</i>)

## Tomorrow's Schools
 
 <i>phr.</i>

>  The Education Ministry had been deliberately allowed to become a spectator of school failure in the 10 years since the introduction of the Tomorrow's Schools model... >  The Tomorrow's Schools reforms introduced in 1988 gave every school its own governing body and the school structures in existence in October 1989 are the ones that are still in place today. <i>(Jun 12, 2006,NZ Herald,A11</i>)

## tonguer
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>BAKER</b> The now obsolete term <i>tonguer</i> was also in use in the early 1830's, and very likely before it although I have discovered no written records of it prior to 1836. A tonguer was a native or white living in New Zealand who assisted a whaling crew to cut up whales and who also acted in the capacity of an interpreter. These men earned their name not from the act of interpreting, but from the fact that they were given the whale's carcase and tongue to dispose of as they wished. <i>(1941,NZ Slang,13</i>)

>  <b>CAPT JOY</b> ... it was told to me by our toungers [sic, at Cloudy Bay] that the cost [of a shore-hut] was trifling. ... I left them [sc Maoris] Came [sic] on board and despatched the boat the other side for a linguist our tounger. (The Ships all employ Tonguers [sic] and it is a general custom I have acceded on the same terms as others) On his arrival we opened the Subject but they [sc Maoris] were ashamed and finally settled that they would build the house. ... I must not omit here Some mention of what are called tonguers. they [sic] are here 2 and 3 white people who have a boat and some natives on a ship arriving they repair on board to solicit the Job for the ship The terms are that they occasionally furnish a crew to help tow whales they furnish a boats crew to help cut the whale in and do any talking for the captain whose ignorance of the language requires their aid in any matters with the natives. When the whale is cut in they are entitled to the carcass and the tongue which in plentiful Whaling is always left on the carcass and they contrive to get for [sic] 6 to 8 barrels of oil from each carcass but they are in general Blackguards and no dependence can be put in them - Runaways from Ships Mostly. [McNab's ed. fn] The Americans had ... to rely to a great extent upon Maori labour and to be indebted to the services of interpreters. These men were locally [?Cloudy Bay] called `tonguers'. ... In `The Piraki Log' [1911] the word `tonguer' is suggested as a corruption of the Maori `tonga'. This is quite wrong. The tonguer was a man who interpreted and assisted in cutting up and who was paid with the tongue of the whale.[choose between this and following citation???] <i>(Apr 28, 1835,Log of Mary Mitchell</i>) [NOTES: 1836 Apr 28 Capt. Joy Log of Mary Mitchell in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 435, 436]

>  <b>CAPT JOY</b> The Principal Chief (Te Rauparaha) is absent on one of his marauding traverses like the Ancient bands (of) Pirates and his authority delegated to 3 chiefs 1 on the western shore the other 2 here ... I despatched the boat the other side for a linguist or tonguer ... I must not omit here Some[sic] mention of what are called touguers. They are here 2 or 3 white people who have a boat [40] and some natives. On a ship arriving they repair on board to solicit the Job for the ship. The terms are that they occasionally furnish a crew to help tow whales, they furnish a boats crew to help cut the whale in and do any talking for the Captain whose ignorance of the language requires their aid in any matters with the natives. When the whale is cut in they are entitled to the carcass & the tongue which in plentiful Whaling is always left on the carcass and they contrive to get from 6 to 8 barrels of oil from each carcass but they are in general Blackguards and no dependence can be put in them - Runaways from Ships Mostly. <i>(Apr 28, 1836,Log of Mary Mitchell,39</i>)

>  [He] found it to be James Robinson, the <i>Tonguer</i> from Wongooloa [ed Anson note Glossary 166: The word is obviously a corruption of the Maori `tonga' meaning `from the South', or `Southerner'; ... ] <i>(Apr 10, 1839,Piraki Log,82</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSON</b> After the ships had cut off the blubber ... the carcase was towed on shore by a crew of men, who call themselves `tonguers'. These men take off what little blubber the ship's crew have passed over, and also take out the tongue and try it all out. <i>(1840,Plain Truths,60</i>)

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> The tongue was of a white or ash colour, blackish towards the root. This organ gave several barrels of oil, and is a monopoly of the `tonguer,' or `cutter-in.' >  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> The ["tonguer"]takes his name from having an exclusive right to the oil obtained from the tongue and other interior parts of the whale in payment for his duty of `cutting in', or dissecting the whale. <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,1/323</i>)

Among the English-speaking whalers these men were called `tonguers'. <i>(1913,Old Whaling Days,194</i>) [NOTES: [see also 1836 citations???]]

## tooth-leaved beech
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Nothofagus fusca</i> [[So Kirk, Botany Thames Goldfields TrNZI 1869 90]] (See [beech](../B#beech))

>  The tooth-leaved beech (<i>Fagus fusca</i>) occurs in considerable quantity at the sea level ... <i>(1879,TrNZI,11/445</i>) [NOTES: (Kirk Hauraki Gulf)]

>  [<i>Notho]fagus fusca</i>,Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occurred in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood. <i>Ibid.</i> 302 All the men engaged at the sawmills [of West Oxford] had heard of `tooth-leaved beech,' but only one or two of them had seen it growing, and no one had seen it converted. TOOTH-LEAVED B. <i>F. fusca</i>, Hook f. All these, however, are commonly called<i> Birches. </i> <i>(1885,TrNZI,17/300</i>) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches),]

>  <b>KIRK</b> With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For <i>Fagus fusca</i>, tooth-leaved beech; for <i>Fagus solandri</i>, entire-leaved beech; and for <i>Fagus menziesii</i>, round-leaved beech. <i>(1875,Durability NZ Timbers,17</i>)

>  The utmost confusion prevails among the common names of the birches. There are scarcely two districts, a few miles apart, in which the same name is applied to the same tree, and a similar result may be obtained by consulting two bushmen in the same bush. With a view to obviating this difficulty Mr Kirk suggests `the adoption of new names based of the obvious characteristics of foliage [e.g.] for Fagus fusca `tooth-leaved beech'; for Fagus solandri `entire-leaved beech' etc. [This is unsuitable as foliage varies] I would suggest the retention of the common Otago names Fagus fusca - Red birch ; F. solandri - Black-heart birch ; F Menziesii - Silver birch. <i>(1876,TrNZI,64/</i>) [NOTES: (Blair),]

>  <i>(1880,TrNZI,12/</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <b>KIRK</b> <i>(1889,Forest Flora</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <i>Beech</i> ... In New Zealand, there are six species of true beeches, which according to Kirk are as follows - ... <i>(1908,AJHR</i>) [NOTES: Cockayne: Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park (And)]

## torching
 
 <i>n.</i> catching fish, or muttonbirds, by dazzling them with torchlight [ca1935 Havelock e.g. Go torching on the mudflats.] (See [cf. spotlighting](../S#spotlighting))

>  <b>BAILEY & ROTH</b> We catch all our birds in the torching,/ And after the cleaning we're scorching;/ <i>(1967,Shanties,136</i>)

>  <b>DEMPSEY</b> It is during this period that mutton-birders go out at night, `torching', catching the young birds which are often found at the entrance to their burrows. <i>(1964,Little World of Stewart island,60</i>)

>  ... the hunting system [for muttonbirds] known as `torching' which takes place right at the end of the season ... <i>(Mar 5, 1966,Dominion,6</i>)

>  <b>JENKINS</b> This would account for the fact that it is heard only at torching time, after most of the adult birds have left the island, and when muttonbirders search out the young birds by torchlight. <i>(1970,NZ Mysteries,156</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Ever since the beginning, to `take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... to `take' also includes an `attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu. <i>Ibid.</i> 68 The `torching' season became known as such because the birders used flaming torches thick enough to be held aloft comfortably grasped in the hand. They were about three feet long and well soaked in muttonbird fat, before being set alight and were made from dry tree branches. Piles of these `torches' were prepared and set aside awaiting [69] the start of the `torching' and each family had their torch bearers. In most cases this duty was carried out by the children. Gradually this primitive method of `lighting the way' gave place to the European kerosene lantern and when supplies of kerosene were exhausted a lighted candle was sometimes used inside the glass globe of the lantern. <i>(1979,Titi Heritage,55</i>)

>  <b>SANSOM</b> First part of the work over except for scrapings. Coming up to torching time. Birds excellent in quality and quantity. <i>(1982,In the Grip of an Island,153</i>)

>  About April 20 the birds start coming out of their burrows and torching begins. <i>(Oct 14, 1953,NZ Observer,16</i>)

>  The 'torching' season become known as such because the birders, used flaming torches thick enough to be held aloft comfortably grasped in the hand. <i>(1979,Titi Heritage,68</i>)

## totalisator
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  From the birdcage, the people would walk to the totalisator. <i>(Nov 18, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,3</i>)
