>  <b>PHILLIPS</b> By the late 1870s a monster in the form of the totalisator (primitive as it was at that stage) raised its head to leer in the direction of the bookies. The warning became louder in 1879 when the Wellingtonc orrespondent of the <i>Lyttelton Times</i> telegraphed:'... that it is proposed to amend the Lotteries Act so as to legalise the totalisator"... In 1880 a Mr Ekberg patented an elementary type of totalisator which was first used at the Canterbury Jockey Club in that year. <i>(2000,First Past the Post,89</i>) [NOTES: Miriam Redwood "I lay the Field" in <Proud Silk</i> 1979]

It was first used in Riccarton by [47] the Canterbury Jockey Club. ... Public opposition continued to flourish and in 1896 a Bill to abolish the totalisator was narrowly defeated. <i>(Jun 2005,NZ Memories,No 54, p. 46</i>)

## towai
 
 <i>n.</i> a tall spreading forest tree of the North Island, related to the kamahi. [Maori towai[o-macron]]. also called tawhero; <i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>, kamahi (in the n. North Island <i>W. sylvicola,</i> tawhero) [TOWAI( or TAWHERO) <i>W. silvicola</i> up to 15m. n.NI to 38 lat.; <i>W. racemosa </i> kamahi takes over from about 37 lat. southwards (from Manukau south) and is the `red birch' of Westland]

>  <i>To&#769;.wa-i </i>(t&omacr.&#769;.wa.&ibreve. or t&omacr.&#769;.-w&imacr.),<i> n</i>. [Maori.] <i>(Bot.)</i> A New Zealand saxifragaceous tree (<i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>); - called also <i>birch. [Local, N. Z.] </i> <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032</i>)

>  <b>NICHOLAS</b> ... towha,another species of pine, not so large as the totara, small, narrow leaf, smooth bark, berry.[check that this is towai] <i>Ibid.</i> Nicholas NZ 2/245 The trees which the natives chiefly make subservient to their purposes, are [besides the pines cowrie, totarra, towha and zarida mentioned above] ... the henow, from which they extract a black dye, the towha, a tree resembling the sycamore, the <i>river river</i>, the grain of whose wood is similar to that of the beech, a species of cork-tree, called by these people vow, a large tree named eckoha, and another named kycata, a tall and beautiful tree, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 1/330 The<i> towha</i>, another species of pine, though not so large as the <i>totarra</i>, grew here [Waimate, Northland] at the same time to a considerable size, and the forest abounded with it. This tree has likewise a small and narrow leaf, but its bark is thin and quite smooth; it bears a berry which is eaten by the natives. <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/329</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> Many other trees abounded in Pamaki [a's-acute], such as the kaikatea [a2-acute], towai, rewa-rewa, totara [a's-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], kahika [a2-acute], tipow, tanikaha [a2-acute], rimu, and various kinds of akkas, all of which will be found described in the Appendix (Note 7). <i>Ibid.</i> 2/396 The <i>Towai, (a<i> podocarpus</i>,) is but a small tree compared with those preceding. The wood is heavy and but little used hitherto. <i>(1838,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/109</i>)

>  <b>HEAPHY</b> The red pines are the <i>Totara, Towa, Mahi</i>, and <i>Rata</i>, all of which are close-grained, and moderately hard. They are used principally for interior work, in house-building, and for furniture-making. They are all of a red colour, and when oiled and polished are very ornamental. ... All these red firs make good spars for ships, and are frequently used by vessels visiting the settlements. The Towa spars are considered the best for this purpose. The fore-yard of the <i>Tory</i>, a 400 ton ship, was made from a green <i>towa</i> spar obtained in Queen Charlotte's Sound, which stood many severe tests without sustaining any injury. ... The only fault of this wood is its weight, but in that respect it is less objectionable than the teak which is used for the masts of all Indian-built vessels. [43] ... The <i>Towa</i> and the <i>Kraka</i> berries also yield an useful oil, but not in such quantity as that first mentioned. <i>(1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),42</i>)

The Bealey <i>T.</i> (to Hororata) is oftener than not called the Bealey road. `We came upon a very bad track-- that is the name by which all roads are called, and they don't deserve a better.'--S.L., p.76. <i>(Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15</i>)

>  In the bush or in the open do you tramp on a <i>track</i>, a <i>trail</i>, or a <i>path</i>? Not on a path one may be sure, seldom if ever on a trail, almost always on a track, like a proper New Zealander... <i>Track</i> is undoubtedly the established word in New Zealand. It is the only one occurring on maps or applied to named routes, such as <i>Hongi's track</i>, the <i>Milford track</i>, the <i>Pahiatua Bush Track Road</i>. ..[25] It is interesting to compare the use of <i>track</i> and<i> trail</i> in <i>The Tramper</i>. Through the first volumes <i>track</i> is always used when referring to an actual track, and <i>trail</i> occurs rarely and then only in the expression <i>blazed trail</i> or more or less figuratively - `to fare forth on the trail'. In 1935 there is the first definite use of <i>trail</i> as a synonym for <i>track</i> in a reference to the `Handbook of Arthur's Pass National Park'. It is significant that it occurs in reference to Arthur's Pass for trail seems to have come into use in Canterbury in this sense before it reached Wellington. It occurs once or twice in the first volume of the <i>Canterbury Mountaineer</i>, and there is the <i>B.B. Trail </i>in the Arthur's Pass Hand book of 1935. From 1939 till 1940 in <i>The Tramper, trail </i>is used moderately frequently for an actual track, e.g. `an old Maori trail', `a miner's trail', but only by the one writer, a Wellington member of the Canterbury Mountaineering Club. <i>Trail</i> shows no sign of ousting <i>track. </i> <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,24</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i>. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through <i>The Tramper, </i> I could not find <i>deer trail</i> used until 1944, but <i>deer track</i> occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. ## trail
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [(contrast track)](../(#(contrast-track)))

>  <b>BEST</b> ... bush trails [alo uses anent, `hapless', `wend his way' etc] <i>(1906,TrNZI,38/159</i>)

>  (Mikonui) ... a foot-track, which branching off near Frew Creek from the Whitcombe Pass trail, leads to Frew Saddle ... <i>(1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.6 (N.S.) 21</i>) [NOTES: 1908 Morgan NZ Geol. Survey Bull. No.6 (N.S.) 21]

>  <b>HYDE</b> There was a dark trail, ... and a stream came with edgings of fine malachite ferns, ... Purple berries lay fallen, rich as damsons but not as big, and good only for the fantails ... <i>(1938,Godwits Fly, The,126,1970 ed.</i>)

>  In the bush or in the open do you tramp on a <i>track, trail</i>, or a <i>path</i>? Not on a path one may be sure, seldom if ever on a trail, almost always on a track, like a proper New Zealander. ... I well remember the shock of astonishment when in 1937 I first saw <i>trail </i>used in New Zealand. The word was on a rough signpost pointing out the beginning of White's Track at Piha. I am afraid I thought somewhat scornfully, `Hm, some townie who has never been out of the city or set foot off a pavement has got all his ideas of New Zealand outdoor life from reading books about North America.'...[25] It is interesting to compare the use of <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i> in <i>The Tramper</i>. Through the first volumes <i>track</i> is always used when referring to an actual track, and <i>trail </i>occurs rarely and then only in the expression <i>blazed trail</i> or more or less figuratively - `to fare forth on the trail'. In 1935 there is the first definite use of<i> trail</i> as a synonym for <i>track</i> in a reference to the `Handbook of Arthur's Pass National Park'. It is significant that it occurs in reference to Arhtur's Pass for trail seems to have come into use in Canterbury in this sense before it reached Wellington. It occurs once or twice in the first volume of the <i>Canterbury Mountaineer</i>, and there is the <i>B.B. Trail</i> in the Arthur's Pass Hand book of 1935. From 1939 till 1940 in <i>The Tramper, trail</i> is used moderately frequently for an actual track, e.g. `an old Maori trail', `a miner's trail', but only by the one writer, a Wellington member of the Canterbury Mountaineering Club. <i>Trail</i> shows no sign of ousting <i>track. </i> <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,24</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 24]

>  In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i> and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hard to follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between<i> track </i>and <i>trail.</i> I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through <i>The Tramper</i>, I could not find <i>deer trail</i> used until 1944, but <i>deer track</i> occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime <i>deer track</i> still seems to be used far more than <i>deer trail.</i> <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,25</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' (deer shooters')]

>  From the top we had seen many deer trails on the other bank, but there were none on our side, so we fought our way down the bank ... <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,35</i>)

## training farm
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a state-run farm where cadets attend a residential course on practical and theoretical aspects of farming. (See [repatriation farm](../R#repatriation-farm))

>  Cadets or students on training-farms should have an occasional lesson in blacksmithing (including horse-shoeing), joinery, and harness-mending. <i>(Feb 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,91</i>)

>  The Director [of Repatriation] .. soon after the passing of the Repatriation Act in 1918, set out, with the assistance of the Department of Agriculture, to establish a training-farm at Tauherenikau, in the Wairarapa district, where returned soldiers suffering from chest trouble could be trained in poultry-keeping, bee-keeping, horticulture and general light farming so as to enable them to take up small holdings of their own under the Discharged Soldiers Settlement Act. The accompanying photographs afford a very good idea of the training-farm. <i>(Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,237</i>)

## tramp metal
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  ... Uranium is soluble, even more so than copper, which is commonly known as `tramp metal', and consequently uranium salts have the ability to move through rocks provided they are porous. <i>(1957,NZ Geog. Society Rec.,24/15</i>)

>  ... uranium is what the old miners used to call `tramp metal' ... What they meant was that it reacts readily with the weak acids in the ground water and the salts of uranium resulting from this reaction are very soluble moving through the space in porous rocks, or the cracks in denser rocks for miles from where they originated. <i>(Sep 10, 1958,Weekly News,4</i>)



## tramper
 
 <i>n.</i> one who travels on foot over rough country for recreation; a hiker; a bush-walker

>  <b>ODELL</b> ... the track to Aicken through the bush was not cut originally to assist trampers and mountaineers, but was made for the purpose of providing a way for a pipe line used during the constructional work on the tunnel. <i>Ibid.</i> 59 The place is a strategic base for mountaineers who wish to conquer the peaks at the head of the Waimakariri, and for trampers on the `Three Pass Trip' (see Harman Pass) it makes a convenient resting place. <i>(1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,27</i>)

>  ... the track to Aicken through the bush was not cut originally to assist trampers and mountaineers, but was made for the purpose of providing a way for a pipe line used during the constructional work on the tunnel. <i>Ibid.</i> 59 The place is a strategic base for mountaineers who wish to conquer the peaks at the head of the Waimakariri, and for trampers on the `Three Pass Trip' (see Harman Pass) it makes a convenient resting place. <i>(1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,27</i>)

## trampoline
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>WHITWORTH</b> I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.) <i>(1879,Spangles and Sawdust,5</i>)

 <i>n.</i> trap rock [OED from 1813, seems universal, no obvious NZ difference]

 <i>n.</i> trapdoor to the cells; or fig.

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [running trap - plumbing and other uses, OED from 1880, doubt any NZ specificity]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [petrol trap; not in OED]

>  <i>Trap, petrol</i>- Trap installed in the drainage system to prevent ingress of petrol into the drainage system and fitted with vent pipes to carry off the petrol vapour <i>(1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [oil trap OED 1863 re coal oil, 1927 re machinery]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [trap-screw; ubiquitous on google but no OED mention]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [anti-siphonage trap; 1989 Charles Ransom notes: Trap, antisiphonage - Not found elsewhere in this form, but Webster II has <i>antisiphon</i> as an adjective designating such a trap.]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [interceptor trap]

>  <i>Trap, interceptor</i>- Trap situated on a drain at some point between a sewer and the lowest inlet to the drain to prevent the passage of air or gases from the sewer to the drain. <i>(1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [neutralizing / neutralising trap]

>  <i>Trap, neutralizing</i>- Trap containing crushed limestone or caustic alkali to neutralize acid waste. <i>(1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [offal trap]

## Treaty trout

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> The sport turned out to be spearing trout. ... Seeing Henry's wonderment, Moses gave him a sly dig in the ribs. `These the treaty trout,' he grinned. `Waitangi, you know, the Maori own all the fish for ever. God bless the Queen!' <i>(1938,Brown Man's Burden,22,1973 ed.</i>)

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> `treaty trout'. A reference to the widely-held belief in a clause of the Treaty of Waitangi, signed in 1840 between Governor Hobson and some of the Maori chiefs, which ostensibly guarantees to Maoris the right to hunt and fish for as long as they wish in the country of which they gave sovereignty to Queen Victoria, the queen Moses blesses. Recent historical research shows that the supposed clause is not present in the Maori text that was signed, though it occurs in some of the variant English versions. ... In any case Maoris have not been exempt from laws restricting fishing and hunting. <i>(1973,Brown Man's Burden,136 [note 11 to p.22]</i>)

## tree avalanche
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  I find that the drowned trees had probably come from what the Fiordlanders call a tree avalanche. Because Fiordland was so thoroughly gouged by glaciers, there is virtually no topsoil on the steeper valley sides. Even the fully-grown forest has only the precarious hold of a woven skin of roots that stretch over rock. This net has a weak grip and if one section tears free it can peel the forest from the cliff-faces in great strips. The fall of just one tree can trigger a tree avalanche. <i>(Jan 1992,NZ Geographic,92</i>)

## Trekka
 
 <i>n.</i> New Zealand's only locally designed and mass-produced motor vehicle

>  "I took a Trekka down to the phonebox - I ran out of petrol - to send a telegram on behalf of the Mt Eden Committee."... The Trekka became known as "the poor man's Land Rover", and many an unfortunate motorist made the mistake of treating their Trekka as if it were a Land Rover, and came to grief when attempting to tackle rough terrain... Even so, the maker found it necessary to suggest to new Trekka owners that "if the engine fails to start ... a push start may be sufficient." <i>(Dec 31, 2001,Dominion,8</i>)

>  Making the boxy Trekka the centre of New Zealand's contribution to the 2003 Venice Biennale bemused New Zealanders, as well as those who visited. ... The Trekka is an extinct fossil that led nowhere, not even to a kiwi or tuatara, which if clunky, have at least survived millions of years. <i>(Nov 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43</i>)

>  You are right, Brian Easton, the Trekka was but a fleeting moment in our manufacturing history ... but the Trekka existed. <i>(Nov 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8</i>)

>  Four "arts ambassadors" from public galleries will spend six weeks working as attendants at the New Zealand exhibition, <i>This is the Trekka</i>, at the 50th Venice Biennale of Art. <i>(May 27, 2003,Dominion Post,A10</i>)

>  Yes, yes, that ruffled bikini looks fetching, and you've got to love those surfboards, but the star of the picture is the Trekka - a forgotten New Zealand design classic... It's a brilliant story, New Zealand's only locally designed and mass-produced motor vehicle, the Trekka, was the brainchild of Noel Turner, a millionaire who supported Labour. The first Trekka rolled off his assembly line in Otahuhu ion 1966. It came in two colours... It had a four cylinder engine, and took 11 gallons in the tank... Turner's formula was a Skoda mechanical kit, bought at basement prices from Czechoslovakia, bolted to a simple boxy body. <i>(Apr 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65</i>)

>  Stevenson has transformed the church into an Iron Curtain-style trade fair exhibition, taking its cue from the Trekka, the only New Zealand-designed and mass-produced motor vehicle, which was based on mechanical components from then-communist Czechoslovakia... The Trekka was the ultimate product of a mnyriad of import restrictions in the 1960s, designed to foster motor vehicle assembly in New Zealand. It was loved by those who admired it's [sic] cheap no-nonsense style as a Land Rover lookalike... "The Trekka is a way of repsenting the idea of New Zealand as an industrialised state, an example of what New Zealand in those days could become"... <i>(Jun 22, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),26</i>)

>  SERIOLELLA BRAMA (Gunther[u-dieresis]). <i>Warehou.</i> Commonly sold as `trevally' in Christchurch and Dunedin. Rare at Bay of Plenty and Auckland. ... >  <b>GRAHAM</b> WAREHOU <i>Seriolella brama</i>(Gunther) In Otago, commercial and sport fishermen, auctioneers, retailers, consumers of fish and readers generally have for many years been giving the name Trevally (Usacaranx lutescens) to small Warehou up to twelve inches in length. It is to be hoped that this misnomer will continue to be replaced by the proper name of Warehou. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,218</i>)

>  <b>PARROTT</b> The Warehou is a southern fish becoming less plentiful in the North Island. It is known as the Trevally, and sold under this name, in Dunedin and Christchurch. It is an excellent food fish, and is always in good demand. It is also found in Australia where it is known as the `Whario' a corruption of the Maori name Wharehou, and in Tasmania it is sold as `Snogtail' Trevally. <i>Ibid.</i> 170 Warehou Seriolella brama Trevally; Sea Bream <i>(1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,65</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> It should be noted that the name sometimes varies according to district. ## tribute
 
 <i>n.</i> (mining)

>  <b>LYON</b> As the quartz mines began to decline in output and could no longer pay a large wage sheet, it became the custom to let them on tribute, by which parties of men were given the right to mine and raise quartz from the resultant crushing, of which a proportionate share of the gold went to the company. This system might also apply to old workings of mines in actual work, but in most of these cases the tributors followed a thin but valuable lead, which might not be much thicker than a finger, but so rich as to be worth tunnelling or working as a tribute, in which the golden lead was pursued on an upward slope. It used to be rather shrewdly suspected that tributors were not `working on the blind' but had as former employees of the company marked a lead and covered the same by a piece of mine timber or rubble till a later date give them the chance to profit by their knowledge. Many of the tributors did exceedingly well; they had nothing except their labour to lose, and the company got some profit on a good lead, and so `where's the harm?' <i>(1952,Faring South,168</i>)

>  And yet in June, 1928, right in the middle of the rising tide of production, the Paparoa Coal Company was forced, for financial reasons, to lay off 85 men and close the mine. Their offer to allow the mine to be worked under tribute (which it was for several years) was bitterly opposed by the unions which claimed that the co-operative system meant the speeding of production at the expense of conditions, and that the people working in co-operative systems were little concerned about the conditions that had been built up through industrial organisation and effort over a long time. <i>(Nov 9, 1972,Press, The,5</i>)

>  After being worked for a preiod [sic] on tribute, mining operations ceased, but the right to the valuable water race was kept intact. <i>(Apr 8, 1918,Grey River Argus,2</i>)

A piece of raw hide known as a knocker is now used to prevent the shears clashing when closed, but before this was introduced the clack and snap of steel meeting steel was a noise inseparable from any busy shearing shed. <i>(1938,High Country,84</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Broom in hand, the fleecie would dash back down the board to sweep up the `locks' and `trimmings'. <i>(1949,High Country Days,51</i>)

>  <b>SCRYMGEOUR</b> Reaching the end of the walk, and things just going fair, he returned and again said to the tall Moree Myall, `You are still cutting too often - go easy,' but the light limbed Australian continued to strip the `Basil' from the unfortunate stud ewe he was shearing. ## trot
 
 <i>n.</i> (in two-up) a succession of heads, esp. in throw a trot, do a trot

>  The boys [were] having a bit of a spin up, and he hopped into the ring, and did a trot for 700 francs. <i>(Sep 5, 1917,2NZEF Times,28</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> Sometimes a man would succeed daringly, doubling up and breaking the ring with a long run of heads, `throwing a trot'. <i>(1937,Civilian into Soldier,99</i>)

>  <b>BRUNO</b> Some ... who had ... struck a trot of `heads' at two-up. <i>(1944,Desert Daze,20 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Trot.</i> 4. A succession of heads thrown at two-up: Australians' and New Zealanders': late C. 19-20. I.e. <i>trot</i> = a run. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,911</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> . [re game of two-up; also trot up]

>  They had been `trotted' in usual way to 4s 6d or 5s. `Trotted' meant puffed up by fictitious bids. <i>(Aug 24, 1912,NZ Truth,374/7/2</i>)

>  Do you know he was bidding for her that day? - No. Didn't you `trot' him up when he was bidding for your younger brother and your mother? - No, I didn't. <i>(Oct 9, 1909,NZ Truth,224/6/1</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> a common NZ variant of OED 4d. <i>trot out</i> (a woman), to walk with as a lover (1888)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> I'm trotting a sheila. <i>(1946,That Summer,33</i>) [NOTES: (`Pair of Socks')]

>  <b>SLATTER</b> And past the Y.W.C.A. where I trotted out a girl once for a few weeks until I found out she had a steady down in Oamaru. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,190</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> trot (a sheila): take out regularly, court. <i>(1964,Collected Stories,304</i>) [NOTES: 1964 Pearson Glossary to 1964 Sargeson Collected Stories 1935-1963 304]

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Me trotting a sheila, dressmaker from Rintoul Street at the time. <i>(1983,Down from Marble Mountain,278</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to present false bids at a stock auction.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> trot: to take fictitious bids at auction. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,87</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> "You are "trotting" me, Mr Auctioneer!" <i>(1996,Trouble with Stock Agents, The,26</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> any run of luck [often as rough trot, cf. rough spin (see spin)]

>  "Hamish is in a trot now that he hasn't experienced before in his international career, but he's a good enough player to come out of it." <i>(Oct 25, 2005,Dominion Post,C14</i>)

>  10 In letters to a friend in Hastings Jerry Monahan states that he is having a good trot, and paper clippings accompanying the letters bear this out. Monahan beat Jamito for the light weight championship of the Orient, and another he beat was Young Pelky. <i>(Jan 17, 1925,NZ Truth,10</i>)

>  THERE is one way to make the money go and that is to stick to a jockey who is having a bad trot. <i>(Oct 30, 1944,NZ Truth,13</i>)

>  Foxchase is experiencing a bad "trot," which went a further stage at Riccarton on Saturday. <i>(Aug 9, 1944,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>trot </iluck, usually in `bad trot' or `good trot', mostly sport use; probably from two-up game, where a trot is a sequence of heads; eg `It's ages since I had a decent trot.' - <i>on the trot</i> a sequence, often a winning one, more usually picking a succession of horse race winners nowadays. - <i>do a trot</i> have a good run of luck. <i>trot</i> a woman, perhaps desired, as used by Gordon Slatter; probably a lightening of English word `trot', whore; c.1925. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115</i>)

## tucker ground
 
 <i>n.</i> OED: 6. [f. TUCK n.1 6 or v.1 10.] The daily supply of food of a gold-digger or station-hand; rations, meals; also, food generally, victuals: = TUCK n.1 6b. to earn or make one's tucker, to earn merely enough to pay for one's keep. Austral. and N.Z. slang.



 
 <i>n.</i> auriferous ground on which merely bare tucker can be made (cf wages ground; payable) [aka tucker-ground]

The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. [abbrev. of Tukuroirangi, Maori]. 2. v. intr. (sl). 1. offer to sell an interview on a matter of importance when a Member of Parliament. <i>(Jun 7, 1997,Dominion,20</i>)

## tumatakahuki
 
 <i>n.</i> tukutuku pattern [ORIGIN: Maori, (from kiwianatown.co.nz) Tukutuku are intricately woven panels often found lining the walls of the Wharenui (meeting house). These panels express ideas from Maori mythology, philosophy and history. The patterns displayed here are : Tumatakahuki (pattern either side) double/triple binding which ensures strength. Poutama (steps) has religious and educational connotations relating to levels of attainment. Roimata Toroa (albatross tears) denoting misadventure particularly to crops. Purapura Whetu (myriad of stars) relates to population and the peopling of a region.]

>  Vertical lines reference tumatakahuki, a procedure which binds the horizontal tukutuku rods in place - an analogy for the kind of frameworks required to maintain the Maori collective. <i>(Nov 23, 2005,NZ Herald,B5</i>)

## turangawaewae

>  Why do they do it? Because Springer gave them a place to be, their very own turangawaewae (spiritual home). <i>(Jun 1, 1999,Dominion,11</i>)

>  For the French, and almost all European winegrowers for that matter, wine is about the land, about a piece of dirt that is turangawaewae. And you can no more separate the land from the wine than you can call a Greek a Turk, or vice versa, which is why Europe is riddled with those convoluted wine regulations that read like a dialogue for a frustrated Homer Simpson - DO, DOG, AoC, VDQS, QmP, QbA! What all these mean is turangawaewae, the place that wine calls home, and there is only one. <i>(Aug 21, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62</i>)

>  <i>Kalik</i>, the final book in Jack Lasenby's "Travellers Quartet", is a satisfying end to the story of Ish and his quest for turangawaewae. <i>((9/0/2002),Listener (New Zealand Listener),62</i>)

>  <i>Kalik</i>, the final book in Jack Lasenby's "Travellers Quartet", is a satisfying end to the story of Ish and his quest for turangawaewae. <i>(Mar 9, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62</i>)

>  Happy because he's bought some land in Rotorua, his turangawaewae after 20 years in Devonport. <i>(Sep 19, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),21</i>)

>  <i>(Feb 17, 1982,Dominion,9</i>) [NOTES: see Incorporations]

>  <b>MARTIN</b> The tussocks referred to are the SNOW TUSSOCK. <i>Danthonia flavescens</i> the RED TUSSOCK (<i>D rigida</i>), and in smaller amount (<i>D.cunninhamii</i>); and the `low tussocks' are chiefly the SILVER TUSSOCK (<i>Poa caespitosa</i>) and the FESCUE TUSSOCK (<i>Festuca novae-zelandiae</i>) or more rarely Poa colensoi, the BLUE TUSSOCK. The name `tussock' is applied to those tufted grasses which hold water in the decaying leaves at the base. Tall tussock is dominant in subalpine regions and low tussock in montane and lowland country, though in Southland the red tussock reaches sea level and dominates much of the landscape. <i>(1961,Flora NZ,129</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Tutu</i>, or <i>Toot, n</i>. Maori name for a shrub or small tree, <i>Coriaria ruscifolia,</i> Linn., or <i>C. sarmentosa,</i> Forst., of New Zealand, widely distributed. It bears greenish flowers, and shiny pulpy black berries. From these the Maoris make a wine resembling light claret, taking care to strain out and not to crush the seeds, which are poisonous, with an action similar to that of strychnine. It goes also by the name of <i>Wineberry-bush</i>, and the Maori name is Anglicised into <i>Toot.</i> In Maori, the final <i>u</i> is swallowed rather than pronounced. In English names derived from the Maori, a vowel after a mute letter is not sounded. It is called in the North Island <i>Tupakihi.</i> In Maori, the verb <i>tutu</i> means to be hit, wounded, or vehemently wild, and the name of the plant thus seems to be connected with the effects produced by its poison. To `eat your toot': used as a slang phrase; to become acclimatised, to settle down into colonial ways. <i>(1898,Austral English,485</i>)

## Twelve Apostles
 
 <i>n.</i> see 1908 citation

>  The recent calls to the Legislative Council are giving rise to speculation as to whether the "Twelve Apostles" called in 1892 are likely to be re-appointed should the present Government be in office in October next. <i>(Jun 24, 1898,Nelson Evening Mail,3</i>)

>  The death of the Hon. Feldwick removes another of the "twelve apostles," by which name the dozen members of the Legislative Council first appointed under the seven years system in 1892 were known. <i>(Aug 8, 1908,Wanganui Herald,5</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural, historical) twelve holders of large valuable Maori land holdings in Hawke's Bay, subject of a special commission in 1873

>  <b>CW RICHMOND</b> There were no small farmers. The Twelve Apostles hold the agricultural lands. <i>(Dec 11, 1879,Letter,471</i>) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers II]

>  .. a block of the fattest land in the colony - was parcelled out amongst a syndicate of twelve gentlemen, notoriously known as the twelve apostles. <i>(Oct 8, 1887,Weekly News,8</i>)

>  'You've seen, my lad,' he pronounced, 'country that for years past has been an out-station of the Kereru run - land owned by the 'Twelve Apostles.' <i>(Jul 8, 1953,Free Lance,33</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> The names of twelve owners of these properties were so much in the news at the time that they came to be known as 'The Twelve Apostles.' <i>(1958,Story of Hawke's Bay, The,171</i>)

>  <b>CAMPBELL</b> Thomas Tanner, who acted as chief negotiator for the purchasers (locally known as the Twelve Apostles) began with an extra-legal lease before the block went before the Native Land Court. <i>(1972,Evolution of Hawke's Bay Landed Society,54</i>)

>  <b>ROLLESTON</b> The notoriety of the defendants gave rise to their being called, variously the Twelve Apostles (actually, only seven were involved in the ownership of twelve shares) or the Forty Thieves. <i>(1980,Master, The,96</i>)

>  <b>BOYD</b> A rival of <i>The Hawke's Bay Herald, The Times</i> had increased its circulation prodigiously by publishing articles headed <i>Acts of the Apostles</i> and <i>Apostolic Creed</i>. Though there were 7 leases and 12 shares, not 12 apostles, the name stuck. <i>(1984,City of the Plains,12</i>) [NOTES: <i>Thomas Tanner and partners leased the Hastings Block in 1867 and purchased it in 1870, thus avoiding laws against purchasing land from the Maoris - the book is in the Beaglehole Collection</i>]

>  They were retained, for GBP300 to do all that the Heretaunga people required - I mean the "twelve apostles." <i>(1877,NZ Parliamentary Debates,XXV/316</i>)

>  I wish to illustrate what I mean by referring to the purchase of land in the Hawke's Bay District by the gentlemen who are known as "the Twelve Apostles."...Owing to the action taken by those "Apostles." the land has been largely increased in value. <i>(Sep 21, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2</i>)

>  The Napier Telegraph has treated the Twelve Apostles of Hawke's Bay to some healthy reading for once. <i>(Nov 15, 1890,NZ Observer,1</i>)

>  Re railway gold passes, it is said ex-members have lost their [sic]; if so, call in all that are left and issue leather ones - the same as has been supplied to the twelve apostles and Sir R. Stout. <i>(Aug 14, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,4</i>)

>  He (Tiwai) overtook them in the ranges on their way to the Twelve Apostles, who are, I believe, somewhere inland. They are going for the purpose of consulting the Twelve and other Hau Hau tribes to commence hostilities in this quarter. <i>(May 3, 1867,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  Had a conscientious person been there to value the land he would have assessed it as L180 an acre. This was a property among the Hawke's Bay twelve apostles' acquisitions. <i>(Feb 21, 1905,Wanganui Herald,2</i>)

>  <b>SHERWOOD</b> It was a Hastings lawyer did the fixing, to keep it out of the papers. He acts for a lot of those awesome Hawkes Bay families who came over with the Twelve Apostles. [fn] A nickname for the Founding Fathers of the town of of Hastings. <i>(1985,Botanist at Bay,129</i>)

>  There is a Tory Party - or, in other words, what they call the land-grabbers, or "Twelve Apostles" in Hawke's Bay. <i>(1895,NZ Parliamentary Debates,84/182</i>)

## twitch
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  It appears that he was twitching a chain with a crowbar, when it broke, smashing and tearing away his nose. <i>(Aug 1, 1907,Feilding Star,2</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [OED 6. vb draw tight by means of a cord (dial); check EDD] (See [also vbl n twitching](../A#also-vbl-n-twitching))

>  <b>R. GILBERD</b> The old method of tightening the chain securing the logs to trucks is called `twitching', or `taking a twitch'. First the chain is fastened leaving it quite slack. A lever is pased through the bight and used to twist the slack up on itself. When the chain is tight enough the end of the lever is tied to the chain. A `chain-rack' is now used - a giant Hayes wire-strainer. It is sometimes, but improperly, called a `twitch'. `Twitch' is probably an amalgamation of `twist' and `hitch'. <i>(1950,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: Okaihau]



 
 <i>n.</i>

## two-and-a-buck
 
 <i>n.</i> half a crown

>  Following are other local money-names... 2.6d <i>half-bull, half-caser or two-and-a-buck..</i>. <i>(Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)</i>) [NOTES: (Letter from <i>Loafer</i>, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

>  The crown was called a<i> bull</i>, a <i>cartwheel</i>, a <i>caser, five bob</i>, and most familiar of all a <i>dollar</i>, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. The only instance recorded of Cockney rhyming slang term for a coin is <i>Oxford scholar,</i> the derivation from dollar being obvious. The half crown was called a <i>half-dollar</i>, a <i>half-bull, half-caser</i>, <i>two-and-a-kick,</i> and <i>two-and-a-buck</i>. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only <i>two bob</i> being recorded as being in use in New Zealand. <i>(Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> <i>Ages of sheep. </i>Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a <i>lamb</i> until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a <i> hogget </i> until shorn. A male lamb is a <i> ram lamb </i> until castrated, then a <i> wether </i>. A female lamb is a <i> ewe lamb </i>. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a <i> shorn hogget </i> until cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a <i> two-tooth </i>. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a <i> four-tooth, then a <i> six-tooth </i> and then an <i> eight-tooth </i> or <i> full-mouthed </i> sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,94</i>)

## type
 
 <i>n.</i> [ca1945 Wellington Training College Are you types ready yet?]



 
 <i>n.</i> [cf. odd-bod]

>  [Mount Ruapehu] Are you a `type' or an `odd-bod'? It was several days before I fathomed this out. The cry would go up, `Ruapehu types arriving, get cracking'. The best club cups would be sorted out, an official or prominent member would greet the new-comers, show them proudly over the house and dispense tea and hospitality with a cordial air. Then I'd hear, `Odd-bods coming up the track'. A member would supervise his arrival, see that no one entered the club room with nailed boots on, and offer a cup of tea, but there was not that ostentatious display of club china, `eats' and cordiality. I found that a `type' is a member of a recognised club and therefore someone to be treated with respect. An `odd-bod' is also a tramper or mountaineer, but of no specified breed, though entitiled to shelter. The same law holds for bush and mountain; hospitality must be dispensed for folk of the right ilk, so that the billy is always on the boil. But tourists! Well, I'd just hate to be a tourist! They were treated with loftiest contempt. I suppose I come under the heading `odd-bod', vouched for by a `type' ... <i>(Jun 14, 1951,NZ Woman's Weekly,24</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> [an occasional trampers' c.p. [d?] Tramper 16(1):3 [d?] ibid 16(11):4 . Mason notes: Heard occasionally in T.T.C - inference that a person is a poor type, perhaps from army?]
